speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I Thought the King had more aﬀeed the Duke of Albany then Cornwall.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: It did all waies ſeeme ſo to vs,but now in the
diuiſion of the kingdomes, it appeares not which of
the Dukes he values moſt,for equalities are ſo weighed,that cu-
rioſitie in neither, can make choiſe of eithers moytie.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Is not this your ſonne my Lord?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: His breeding ſir hath beene at my charge, I haue ſo of-
ten bluſht to acknowledge him, that now I am braz’d to it.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I cannot conceiue you.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Sir, this young fellowes mother Could, wherupon ſhee
grew round wombed, and had indeed Sir a ſonne for her cradle,
ere ſhe had a huſband for her bed, doe you ſmell a fault?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I cannot wiſh the fault vndone, the iſſue of it being ſo
proper.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: But I haue ſir a ſonne by order of Law, ſome yeare el-
der then this, who yet is no deerer in my account , though this
knaue came ſomething ſawcely into the world before hee was
ſent for, yet was his mother faire, there was good ſport at his
makeing,& the whoreſon muſt be acknowledged, do you know
this noble gentleman Edmund?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: No, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: My Lord of Kent, remember him hereafter as my ho-
norable friend.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: My ſeruices to your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I muſt loue you, and ſue to know you better.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Sir I ſhall ſtudy deſeruing.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Hee hath beene out nine yeares, and away hee ſhall
againe, the King is comming.

scene.stagedir: Sound a Sennet. Enter one bearing a Coronet, then Lear, then the Dukes of Albany, and Cornwell, next Gonorill, Regan, Cordelia, with followers.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Attend my Lords of France and Burgundy, Gloſter.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I ſhall my Leige.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Meane time we will expreſſe our darker purpoſes,
The map there; know, we haue diuided
In three,our kingdome; and tis our ﬁrſt intent,
To ſhake all cares and buſines of our ſtate,
Confirming them on yonger yeares,
The two great Princes France and Burgundy,
Great ryuals in our yongeſt daughters loue,
Long in our Court haue made their amorous ſoiourne,
And here are to be anſwerd, tell me my daughters,
Which of you ſhall we ſay doth loue vs moſt,
That we our largeſt bountie may extend,
Where merit doth moſt challenge it,
Gonorill our eldeſt borne, ſpeake ﬁrſt?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Sir I do loue you more then words can weild the matter,
Dearer then eye-ſight,ſpace or libertie,
Beyond what can be valued rich or rare,
No leſſe then life; with grace, health, beautie, honour,
As much a child ere loued, or father friend,
A loue that makes breath poore, and ſpeech vnable,
Beyond all manner of ſo much I loue you.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: What ſhall Cordelia doe, loue and be ſilent.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Of al theſe bounds, euen from this line to this,
With ſhady forreſts,and wide skirted meades,
We make thee Lady, to thine and Albanies iſſue,
Be this perpetuall, what ſaies our ſecond daughter?
Our deereſt Regan, wife to Cornwell, ſpeake?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Sir I am made of the ſelfe ſame mettall as my ſiſter is,
And prize me at her worth in my true heart,
I find ſhe names my very deed of loue, onely ſhe came ſhort,
That I profeſſe my ſelfe an enemie to all other ioyes,
Which the moſt precious ſquare of ſence profeſſes,
And find I am alone felicitate, in your deere highnes loue.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Then poore Cord. & yet not ſo, ſince I am ſure
My loues more richer then my tongue.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: To thee and thine hereditarie euer
Remaine this ample third of our faire kingdome,
No leſſe in ſpace, validity, and pleaſure,
Then that confirm’d on Gonorill, but now our ioy,
Although the laſt, not leaſt; in our deere loue,
What can you ſay to win a third, more opulent
Then your ſiſters.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Nothing my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: How, nothing can come of nothing, ſpeake againe.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Vnhappie that I am, I cannot heaue my heart into my
mouth,I loue your Maieſtie according to my bond, not more not
leſſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Goe to,goe to, mend your ſpeech a little,
Leaſt it may mar your fortunes.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Good my Lord,
You haue begot me, bred me, loued me,
I returne thoſe duties backe as they are right ﬁt,
Obey you, loue you, and moſt honour you,
Why haue my ſiſters huſbands, if they ſay they loue you all,
Happely when I ſhall wed, tha Lord whoſe hand
Muſt take my plight, ſhall cary halfe my loue with him,
Halfe my care, and duty, fure I ſhall neuer
Mary like my ſiſters, to loue my father all.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: But goes this with thy heart?

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: I good my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: So young and ſo vntender,

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: So yong my Lord and true.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Well let it be ſo, thy truth then be thy dower,
For by the ſacred radience of the Sunne,
The miſtreſſe of Heccat, and the might,
By all the operation of the orbs,
From whome we doe exſiſt and ceaſe to be
Heere I diſclaime all my paternall care,
Propinquitie and property of blood,
And as a ſtranger to my heart and me
Hould thee from this for euer, the barbarous Scythyan,
Or he that makes his generation
Meſſes to gorge his appetite
Shall bee as well neighbour’d, pittyed and relieued:
As thou my ſometime daughter.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Good my Liege.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Peace Kent,come not between the Dragon & his wrath,
I lou’d her moſt, and thought to ſet my reſt
On her kind nurcery, hence and auoide my ſight:
So be my graue my peace as here I giue,
Her fathers heart from her, call France, who ſtirres?
Call Burgundy, Cornwell, and Albany,
With my two daughters dower digeſt this third,
Let pride, which ſhe cals plainnes, marrie her:
I doe inueſt you iointly in my powre,
Preheminence, and all the large eﬀes
That troope with Maieſtie, our ſelfe by monthly courſe
With reſeruation of an hundred knights,
By you to be ſuſtayn’d, ſhall our abode
Make with you by due turnes, onely we ſtill retaine
The name and all the additions to a King,
The ſway, reuenue, execution of the reſt,
Beloued ſonnes be yours, which to conﬁrme,
This Coronet part betwixt you.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Royall Lear,
Whom I haue euer honor’d as my King.
Lou’d as my Father, as my maiſter followed,
As my great patron thought on in my prayers.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: The bow is bēt & drawen make from the ſhaft.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Let it fall rather,
Though the forke inuade the region of my heart,
Be Kent vnmannerly when Lear is man,
What wilt thou doe ould man, think’ſt thou that dutie
Shall haue dread to ſpeake, when power to ﬂatterie bowes,
To plainnes honours bound
When Maieſty ſtoops to folly,
Reuerſe thy doome, and in thy beſt conſideration
Checke this hideous raſhnes, anſwere my life
My iudgement, thy yongeſt daughter does not loue thee leaft,
Nor are thoſe empty harted whoſe low, ſound
Reuerbs no hollownes.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Kent on thy life no more.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: My life I neuer held but as pawne
To wage againſt thy enemies, nor feare to loſe it
Thy ſafety being motiue.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Out of my ſight.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: See better Lear and let me ſtill remaine,
The true blanke of thine eye.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Now by Apollo,

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Now by Apollo King thou ſweareſt thy Gods in vaine.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Vaſſall,recreant.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Doe,kill thy Phyſicion,
And the fee beſtow vpon the foule diſeaſe,
Reuoke thy doome,or whilſt I can vent clamour
From my throat, ile tell thee thou doſt evill.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Heare me,on thy allegeance heare me?
Since thou haſt ſought to make vs breake our vow,
Which we durſt neuer yet; and with ſtraied pride,
To come betweene our ſentence and our powre,
Which nor our nature nor our place can beare,
Our potency made good, take thy reward.
Foure dayes we doe allot thee for prouiſion,
To ſhield thee from diſeaſes of the world,
And on the ﬁſt to turne thy hated backe
Vpon our kingdome, if on the tenth day following,
Thy baniſht truncke be found in our dominions,
The moment is thy death, away, by Iupiter,
This ſhall not be reuokt.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Why fare thee well king, ſince thus thou wilt appeare,
Friendſhip liues hence, and baniſhment is here,
The Gods to their proteion take the maide,
That rightly thinkſ,and haſt moſt iuſtly ſaid,
And your large ſpeeches may your deeds approue,
That good eﬀes may ſpring from wordes of loue:
Thus Kent O Princes, bids you all adew,
Heele ſhape his old courſe in a countrie new.

scene.stagedir: Enter France and Burgundie with Gloſter.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Heers France and Burgundie my noble Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: My L. of Burgūdie, we ﬁrſt addres towards you,
Who with a King hath riuald for our daughter,
What in the leaſt will you require in preſent
Dower with her, or ceaſe your queſt of loue?

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: Royall Maieſty,I craue no more then what
Your highnes oﬀered,nor will you tender leſſe?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Right Noble Burgundie,when ſhe was deere to vs
We did hold her ſo,but now her priſe is fallen,
Sir there ſhe ſtands, if ought within that little
Seeming ſubſtāce,or al of it with our diſpleaſure peec’ྏt,
And nothing elſ may ﬁtly like your grace,
Shees there, and ſhe is yours.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: I know no anſwer.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Sir will you with thoſe inﬁrmities ſhe owes,
Vnfriended,new adopted to our hate,
Couered with our curſe, and ſtranger’d with our oth,
Take her or leaue her.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: Pardon me royall ſir, eleion makes not vp
On ſuch conditions.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Then leaue her ſir,for by the powre that made me
I tell you all her wealth, for you great King,
I would not from your loue make ſuch a ſtray,
To match you where I hate, therefore beſeech you
To auert your liking a more worthier way,
Then on a wretch whome nature is aſhamed
Almoſt to acknowledge hers.

speech.speaker: Fra.
speech.line: This is moſt ſtrange,that ſhe, that euen but now
Was your beſt obie, the argument of your praiſe,
Balme of your age,moſt beſt,moſt deereſt,
Should in this trice of time commit a thing,
So monſtrous to diſmantell ſo many foulds of fauour,
Sure her oﬀence muſt be of ſuch vnnaturall degree,
That monſters it, or you for voucht aﬀeions
Falne into taint, which to beleeue of her
Muſt be a faith that reaſon without miracle
Could neuer plant in me.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: I yet beſeech your Maieſtie,
If for I want that glib and oyly Art,
To ſpeake and purpoſe not,ſince what I well entend
Ile do’t before I ſpeake,that you may know
It is no vicious blot,murder or foulnes,
No vncleane aion or diſhonord ſtep
That hath depriu’d me of your grace and fauour,
But euen for want of that, for which I am rich,
A ſtill ſoliciting eye, and ſuch a tongue,
As I am glad I haue not,though not to haue it,
Hath loſt me in your liking.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Goe to, goe to,better thou hadſt not bin borne,
Then not to haue pleas’d me better.

speech.speaker: Fran.
speech.line: Is it no more but this, a tardines in nature,
That often leaues the hiſtorie vnſpoke that it intends to
My Lord of Burgundie,what ſay you to the Lady? do,
Loue is not loue when it is mingled with reſpes that
Aloofe from the intire point wil you haue her? ſtāds
She is her ſelfe a dowre.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: Royall Leir,giue but that portion
Which your ſelfe prepoſd,and here I take Cordilia
By the hand,Dutches of Burgundie,

speech.speaker: Leir.
speech.line: Nothing, I haue ſworne.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: I am ſory then you haue ſo loſt a father,
That you muſt looſe a huſband.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Peace be with Burgundie,ſince that reſpes
Of fortune are his loue, I ſhall not be his wife.

speech.speaker: Fran.
speech.line: Faireſt Cordelia that art moſt rich being poore,
Moſt choiſe forſaken,and moſt loued deſpiſd,
Thee and thy vertues here I ceaze vpon,
Be it lawfull I take vp whats caſt away.
Gods, Gods! tis ſtrāge,that from their couldſt negle,
My loue ſhould kindle to inﬂam’d reſpe,
Thy dowreles daughter King throwne to thy chance,
Is Queene of vs,of ours,and our faire France:
Not all the Dukes in watriſh Burgundie,
Shall buy this vnprizd precious maide of me,
Bid them farewell Cordelia, though vnkinde
Thou looſeſt here, a better where to ﬁnd.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Thou haſt her France,let her be thine,
For we haue no ſuch daughter,nor ſhall euer ſee
That face of hers againe,therfore be gone,
Without our grace, our loue, our benizon? come noble Burgūdy.

speech.speaker: Fran.
speech.line: Bid farwell to your ſiſters?

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: The iewels of our father,
With waſht eyes Cordelia leaues you, I know you what you are,
And like a ſiſter am moſt loath to call your faults
As they are named, vſe well our Father,
To your profeſſed boſoms I commit him,
But yet alas ſtood I within his grace,
I would preferre him to a better place:
So farewell to you both?

speech.speaker: Gonorill.
speech.line: Preſcribe not vs our duties?

speech.speaker: Regan.
speech.line: Let your ſtudy be to content your Lord,
Who hath receaued you at Fortunes almes,
You haue obedience ſcanted,
And well are worth the worth that you haue wanted.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Time ſhall vnfold what pleated cūuing hides,
Who couers faults,at laſt ſhame derides:
Well may you proſper.

speech.speaker: Fran.
speech.line: Come faire Cordelia?

speech.speaker: Gonor.
speech.line: Siſter,it is not little I haue to ſay,
Of what moſt neerely appertaines to vs both,
I thinke our father will hence to night.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Thats moſt certaine,and with you,next moneth with vs.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: You ſee how full of changes his age is the obſeruation we
haue made of it hath bin little; hee alwaies loued our ſiſter
moſt, and with what poore iudgement hee hath now caſt her
oﬀ,appeares too groſſe.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Tis the inﬁrmitie of his age, yet hee hath euer but ſlen-
derly knowne himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Gono.
speech.line: The beſt and ſoundeſt of his time hath bin but raſh,
then muſt we looke to receiue from his age not alone the imper-
feion of long ingraﬀed condition,but therwithal vnruly way-
wardnes, that inﬁrme and cholericke yeares bring with them.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Such vnconſtant ſtarts are we like to haue from him, as
this of Kents baniſhment.

speech.speaker: ’Gont.
speech.line: There is further complement of leaue taking betweene
France and him,pray lets hit together,if our Father cary autho-
rity with ſuch diſpoſitions as he beares,this laſt ſurrender of his,
will but oﬀend vs,

speech.speaker: Regan.
speech.line: We ſhall further thinke on’t.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: We muſt doe ſomething,and it’h heate.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Thou Nature art my Goddeſſe,to thy law my ſeruices
are bound, wherefore ſhould I ſtand in the plague of cuſtome,
and permit the curioſitie of nations to depriue me, for that I am
ſome twelue or 14 mooneſhines lag of a brother, why baſtard?
wherfore baſe, when my dementions are as well compa, my
mind as generous,and my ſhape as true as honeſt madams iſſue,
why brand they vs with baſe, baſe baſtardie? who in the luſty
ſtealth of nature, take more compoſition and feirce quality,then
doth within a ſtale dull lyed bed, goe to the creating of a whole
tribe of fops got tweene a ſleepe and wake; well the legitimate
Edgar, I muſt haue your land, our Fathers loue is to the baſtard
Edmund, as to the legitimate, well my legitimate, if this letter
ſpeede,and my inuention thriue, Edmundthe baſe ſhall tooth’le-
gitimate :I grow,I proſper,now Gods ſtand vp for Baſtards.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Kent baniſht thus, and France in choller parted, and
the King gone to night, ſubſcribd his power, conﬁned to exhi-
bition, all this donne vpon the gadde? Edmund how now
what newes?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: So pleaſe your Lordſhip, none:

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Why ſo earneſtly ſeeke you to put vp that letter?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I know no newes my Lord.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: What paper were you reading?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Nothing my Lord,

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: No, what needes then that terribe diſpatch of it into
your pocket, the qualitie of nothing hath not ſuch neede to hide
it ſelfe, lets ſee, come if it bee nothing I ſhall not neede ſpea-
cles.

speech.speaker: Ba.
speech.line: I beſeech you Sir pardon me,it is a letter from my brother,
that I haue not all ore read,for ſo much as I haue pernſed, I ﬁnd it
not ﬁt for your liking.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Giue me the letter ſir.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I ſhall oﬀend either to detaine or giue it, the contents
as in part I vnderſtand them, are too blame.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Lets ſee, lets ſee?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I hope for my brothers iuſtiﬁcation, he wrot this but
as an eſſay, or taſt of my vertue.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: This policie of age makes the world bitter to the beſt of our times, keepes our fortunes from vs till our oldnes cannot reliſh them, I begin to ﬁnd an idle and fond bondage in the oppreſſion of aged tyranny, who ſwaies not as it hath power,but as it is ſuﬀered,come to me,that of this I may ſpeake more, if our father would ſleepe till I wakt him, you ſhould inioy halfe his reuenew for euer , and liue the beloued of your brotherEdgar.
Hum? conſpiracie,ſlept till I wakt him,you ſhould enioy halfe his reuenew, my ſonne Edgar, had hee a hand to write this, a hart,and braine to breed it in, when came this to you, who brought it?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: It was not brought me my Lord, there’s the cunning of
it,I found it throwne in at the caſement of my cloſet.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: You know the Caraar to be your brothers?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: If the matter were good,my Lord I durſt ſweare it were
his but in reſpe of that I would faine thinke it were not,

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: It is his ?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: It is his hand my Lord, but I hope his heart is not in
the contents.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Hath he neuer heretofore ſoūded you in this buſines?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Neuer my Lord, but I haue often heard him maintaine
it to be ﬁt, that ſons at perﬁt age,& fathers declining,his father
ſhould be as ward to the ſonne,and the ſonne mannage the re-
uenew.

speech.speaker: Gloſ.
speech.line: O villaine, villaine,his very opinion in the letter, ab-
horred villaine, vnnaturall deteſted brutiſh villaine,worſe then
brutiſh, go ſir ſeeke him,I apprehend him,abhominable villaine
where is he?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I doe not well know my Lord, if it ſhall pleaſe you to
ſuſpend your indignation againſt my brother, til you can deriue
from him better teſtimony of this intent: you ſhould run a cer-
taine courſe, where if you violently proceed againſt him, mi-
ſtaking his purpoſe, it would make a great gap in your owne
honour,& ſhake in peeces the heart of his obediēce,I dare pawn
downe my life for him,he hath wrote this to feele my aﬀeion
to your honour,and to no farther pretence of danger.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Thinke you ſo?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: If your honour iudge it meete, I will place you where
you ſhall heare vs conferre of this,and by an aurigular aſſurance
haue your ſatiſſfaion, and that without any further delay then
this very euening.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: He cannot be ſuch a monſter.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Nor is not ſure.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: To his father,that ſo tenderly and intirely loues him,
heauen and earth !Edmund ſeeke him out, wind mee into him, I
pray you frame your buſines after your own wiſedome, I would
vnſtate my ſelfe to be in a due reſolution.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I will ſhall ſeeke him ſir preſently, conuey the buſineſſe as I
ſhall ſee meanes, and acquaint you withall.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Theſe late eclipſes in the Sunne and Moone portend
no good to vs, though the wiſedome of nature can reaſon thus
and thus, yet nature ﬁnds it ſelfe ſcourg’d by the ſequent eﬀes,
loue cooles, friendſhip fals oﬀ, brothers diuide,in Citties, mu-
tinies, in Countries diſcords, Pallaces treaſon, the bond crackt
betweene ſonne and father; find out this villaine Edmund, it ſhal
looſe thee nothing, doe it carefully,and the noble and true har-
ted Kent baniſht,his oﬀence honeſt, ſtrange ſtrange !

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: This is the excellent foppery of the world, that when
we are ſicke in Fortune,often the ſurfeit of our owne behauiour,
we make guiltie of our diſaſters, the Sunne, the Moone, and the
Starres,as if we were Villaines by neceſſitie, Fooles by heauen-
ly compulſion, Knaues, Theeues, and Trecherers by ഷpirituall predomina-
nce, Drunkards, Lyars
and Adulterers by an enforſt obedience of planitary
inﬂuence, and all that wee are euill in, by a diuine
thruſting on, an admirable euaſion of whoremaſter man,
to lay his gotiſh diſpoſition to the charge of Starres:
my Father compounded with my Mother vnder the Dragons
taile, and my natiuitie was vnder Vrſa maior, ſo
that it followes, I am rough and lecherous, Fut, I ſhould
haue beene that I am,had the maidenleſt ſtarre of the Firmament
twinckled on my baſtardy
Edgar; and out hee comes like the Cataſtrophe of the old Comedy,
mine is villanous melancholy, with a ſith like them of Bedlam; O
theſe eclipſes doe portend theſe diuiſions.

speech.speaker: Edgar.
speech.line: How now brother Edmund, what ſerious contemplation
are you in?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I am thinking brother of a prediion I read this
other day,what ſhould follow theſe Eclipſes.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Doe you buſie your ſelfe about that?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I promiſe you the eﬀes he writ of,ſucceed vnhappily,as of vnnaturalneſſe betweene the child and the parent,
death,dearth,diſſolutions of ancient amities, diuiſions in ſtate,menaces and malediions againſt King and nobles,
needles diſſidences,baniſhment offriēds,diſſipation of Cohorts,nuptial breaches,and I know not what.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: How long haue you beene a ſeary Aſtronomicall?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Come,come, when ſaw you my father laſt?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Why,the night gon by.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Spake you with him?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Two houres together.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Parted you in good tearmes? found you no diſpleaſure in him by word or countenance?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: None at all.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Bethinke your ſelfe wherein you may haue oﬀended
him,and at my intreatie,forbeare his preſence,till ſome little time hath qualiﬁed the heat of his diſpleaſure,
which at this inſtant ſo rageth in him, that with the miſchiefe,
of your parſon it would ſcarce allay.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Some villaine hath done me wrong.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Thats my feare brother, I aduiſe you to the beſt, goe arm’d,
I am no honeſt man if there bee any good meaning towards you, I haue told you what I haue ſeene & heard, but faintly,
nothing like the image and horror of it, pray you away.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Shall I heare from you anon?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I doe ſerue you in this buſines:
A credulous Father,and a brother noble,
Whoſe nature is ſo farre from doing harmes,
That he ſuſpes none, on whoſe fooliſh honeſty
My praiſes ride eaſie, I ſee the buſines.
Let me if not by birth, haue lands by wit,
All with me’s meete, that I can faſhion ﬁt.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Did my Father ſtrike my gentleman for chiding
of his foole?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Yes Madam.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: By day and night he wrongs me,
Euery houre he ﬂaſhes into one groſſe crime or other
That ſets vs all at ods,ile not indure it,
His Knights grow ryotous,and him ſelfe obrayds vs,
On euery trifell when he returnes from hunting,
I will not ſpeake with him, ſay I am ſicke,
If you come ſlacke of former ſeruices,
You ſhall doe well, the fault of it ile anſwere.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Hee’s coming Madam,I heare him.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Put on what wearie negligence you pleaſe,
you and your fellow feruants,i’de haue it come queſtion,if he diſlike it,let him to our ſiſter,
whoſe mind and mine I know in that are one, not to be ouerruld; idle old man that ſtill would manage thoſe
authorities that hee hath giuen away, now by my life old fooles are babes again,& muſt be vs’d with checkes as flatteries,
when they are ſeene abuſd,remember what I tell you.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Very well Madam.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: And let his Knights haue colder looks among
you,what growes of it no matter, aduiſe your fellowes
ſo, I would breed from hence occaſions, and I ſhall. that I may ſpeake,ile write
ſtraight to my ſiſter to hould my very courſe, goe prepare for
dinner.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: If but as well I other accents borrow,
that can my ſpeech defuſe, my good intent
may carry through it ſelfe to that full iſſue
for which I raz’d my likenes, now baniſht Kent,
if thou canſt ſerue where thou doſt ſtand condem’d,
thy maiſter whom thou loueſt
ſhall ﬁnd the full of labour.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Let me not ſtay a iot for dinner, goe get it readie,
how now, what art thou?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: A man Sir.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What doſt thou profeſſe? what would’ſt thou
with vs?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I doe profeſſe to be no leſſe then I ſeeme, to ſerue
him truly that will put me in truſt, to loue him that is
honeſt, to conuerſe with him that is wiſe,and ſayes little, to
feare iudgement, to ﬁght when I cannot chuſe, and to
eate no ﬁſhe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What art thou?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: A very honeſt hearted fellow, and as poore as
the King,that’t poore enough, what would’ſt thou?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: If thou be as poore for a ſubie,as he is for a
King,that’t poore enough, what wouldſt thou?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Seruice.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Who would’ſt thou ſerue?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: You.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Do’ſt thou know me fellow?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: No ſir,but you haue that in your countenance,
which I would ſaine call Maiſter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Whats that?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Authoritie.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What ſeruices canſt doe?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I can keepe honeſt counſaile,ride,run, mar a
curious tale in telling it, and deliuer a plaine meſſage
bluntly, that which ordinarie men are ﬁt for, I am qualiﬁed
in, and the beſt of me, is diligence.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: How old art thou?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Not ſo youg to loue a woman for ſinging,
nor ſo old to dote on her for any thing, I haue yeares on
my backe fortie eight.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Follow mee,thou ſhalt ſerue mee, if I like thee no
worſe after dinner,I will not part from thee yet,dinner,
ho dinner, wher’s my knaue, my foole, goe you and call
my foole hether,you ſirrah,whers my daughter?

speech.speaker: Steward.
speech.line: So pleaſe you,

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What ſay’s the fellow there, call the clat-pole
backe, wher’s my foole, ho I thinke the world’s
aſleepe, how now, wher’s that mungrel?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: He ſay’s my Lord, your daughter is not well.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why came not the ſlaue backe to mee when I
cal’d him?

speech.speaker: ſeruant.
speech.line: Sir, hee anſwered mee in the roundeſt maner, hee
would not.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: A would not?

speech.speaker: ſeruant.
speech.line: My Lord,I know not what the matter is,
but to my iudgemēt, your highnes is not ētertained
with that ceremonious aﬀeion as you were wont,
ther’s a great abatement, apeer’s as well in
the generall dependants, as in the Duke himſelfe also, and
your daughter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ha, ſay’ſt thou ſo?

speech.speaker: ſeruant.
speech.line: I beſeech you pardon mee my Lord,if I be
miſtaken, for my dutie cannot bee ſilent, when I thinke
your highneſſe wrong’d.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Thou but remember’ſt me of mine owne conception,
I haue perceiued a moſt faint negle of late,
which I haue rather blamed as mine owne ielous curioſitie,
then as a very pretence & purport of vnkindneſſe,
I will looke further into’t, but wher’s this foole? I
haue not ſeene him this two dayes.

speech.speaker: ſeruant.
speech.line: Since my yong Ladies going into France
ſir,the foole hath much pined away.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No more of that, I haue noted it, goe you
and tell my daughter,I would ſpeake with her,goe you
cal hither my foole, O you ſir, you ഷir,come you hither,
who am I ſir?

speech.speaker: Steward.
speech.line: My Ladies Father.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: My Ladies father, my Lords knaue, you horeſon
dog, you ſlaue, you cur.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I am none of this my Lord,
I beſeech you pardon me.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Doe you bandie lookes with me you raſcall?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Ile not be ſtruck my Lord,

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Nor tript neither, you baſe football player.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I thanke thee fellow,
thou ſeru’ſt me,and ile loue thee.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Come ſir, ile teach you diﬀerences,
away, away, if you will meaſure your lubbers length againe,
tarry, but away, you haue wiſedome.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Now friendly knaue I thanke thee, ’their’s,
earneſt of thy ſeruice.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Let me hire him too, heer’s my coxcombe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: How now my prety knaue, how do’ſt thou?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Sirra, you were beſt take my coxcombe.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Why Foole?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Why for taking on’s part, that’s out of fauour,
nay and thou can’ſt not ſmile as the wind ſits, thou’t catch
cold ſhortly, there take my coxcombe; why this fellow
hath baniſht two on’s daughters,and done the third a
bleſſing againſt his will, if thou follow him,thou muſt
needs weare my coxcombe, how now nuncle,would
I had two coxcombes, and two daughters.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why my boy?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: If I gaue them any liuing, id’e keepe my coxcombs
my ſelfe, ther’s mine,beg another of thy
daughters.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Take heede ſirra,the whip.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Truth is a dog muſt to kenell, hee muſt bee
whipe out, when the Ladie oth’e brach may ſtand by the ﬁre
and ſtincke.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: A peſtilent gull to mee.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Sirra, ile teach thee a ſpeech.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Doe.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Marke it vncle,
haue more then thou ſheweſt,
ſpeake leſſe then thou knoweſt,
lend leſſe then thou oweſt,
ride more then thou goeſt,
learne more then thou troweſt,
ſet leſſe then thou throweſt,
leaue thy drinke and thy whore,
and keepe in a doore,
and thou ſhalt haue more,
then two tens to a ſcore.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: This is nothing foole.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Then like the breath of an vnfeed Lawyer,
you gaue me nothing for’t, can you make no vſe of nothing vncle?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why no boy,
nothing can be made out of nothing.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Preethe tell him, ſo much the rent of his land
comes to, he will not beleeue a foole.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: A bitter foole.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Doo’ſt know the diﬀerence my boy,betweene
a bitter foole, and a ſweete foole.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No lad, teach mee.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: That Lord that counſail’d thee to giue away thy land,Come place him heere by mee, doe thou for him ſtand,
The ſweet and bitter foole will preſently appeare,The one in motley here,the other found out there.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Do’ſt thou call mee foole boy?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: All thy other Titles thou haſt giuen away, tha thou waſt borne with.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: This is not altogether foole my Lord.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: No faith, Lords and great men will not let me, if I had a monopolie out,they would haue part an’t,and Ladies too,
they will not let me haue all the foole to my ſelfe,they’l be ſnatching; giue me an egge Nuncle,and ile giue thee two crownes.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What two crownes ſhall they be?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Why, after I haue cut the egge in the middle and
eate vp the meate,the two crownes of the egge; when
thou cloueſt thy crowne it’h middle,and gaueſt away
both parts,thou boreſt thy aſſe at’h backe or’e the
durt, thou had’ſt little wit in thy bald crowne,when thou
gaueſt thy golden one away, if I ſpeake like my ſelfe in
this,let him be whipt that ﬁrſt ﬁnds it ſo.
Fooles had nere leſſe wit in a yeare,
For wiſe men are growne foppiſh,
They know not how their wits doe weare,
Their manners are ſo apiſh.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: When were you wont to be ſo full of ſongs ſirrah?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: I haue vs’d it nuncle,euer ſince thou mad’ſt
thy daughters thy mother, for when thou gaueſt them
the rod, and put’ſt downe thine owne breeches, then they
for ſudden ioy did weep,
and I for ſorrow ſung,
that ſuch a King ſhould play bo-peepe,
and goe the fooles among
prethe Nunckle keepe a ſchoolemaſter that can teach
thy foole to lye, I would ſaine learneto lye.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: And you lye, weele haue you whipt.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: I maruell what kin thou and thy daughters are,
they’l haue me whipt for ſpeaking true, thou wilt hauemee
whipt for lying,and ſometime I am whipt for holding
my peace, I had rather be any kind of thing then a foole,
and yet I would not bee thee Nuncle,thou haſt pared thy
wit a both ſides, & left nothing in the middle,here
comes one of the parings.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: How now daughter, what makes that Frontlet
on, Me thinks you are too much alateit’h frowne.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Thou waſt a prettie fellow when thou had’ſt no
need to care for her frowne, now thou art an O without
a ﬁgure, I am better then thou art now, I am a foole,
thou art nothing, yes forſooth I will hould my tongue, ſo
your face bids mee, though you ſay nothing.
Mum, mum,he that keepes neither cruſt nor crum,
Wearie of all, ſhall want ſome. That’s a ſheald peſcod.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Not onely ſir this,your all-licenc’d foole,
but other of your inſolent retinue
do hourely carpe and quarrell, breaking forth
in ranke, & (not to be indured riots,) Sir
I had thought by making this well knowne vnto you,
to haue found a ſafe redres, but now grow fearefull
by what your ſelfe too late haue ſpoke and done,
that you prote this courſe, and put on
by your allowance, which if you ſhould,the fault
would not ſcape cenſure, nor the redreſſe,ſleepe,
which in the tender of a wholſome weale,
might in their working doe you that oﬀence,
that elſe were ſhame,that then neceſſitie
muſt call diſcreet proceedings.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: For you trow nuncle, the hedge ſparrow
fed the Coo, kow ſo long, that it had it head bit oﬀ beit
young,ſo out went the candle,and we were left darkling.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Are you our daughter?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Come ſir,I would you would make vſe of that good wiſedome
whereof I know you are fraught, and put away
theſe diſpoſitions, that of late tranſforme you
from what you rightly are.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: May not an Aſſe know when the cart drawes
the horſe,
whoop Iug I loue thee.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Doth any here know mee?
why this is not Lear,
doth Lear walke thus? ſpeake thus? where are his eyes,
either his notion,weaknes,or his diſcernings
are lethergie,ſleeping,or wakeing; ha! ſure tis not ſo,
who is it that can tell me who I am ?
Lears ſhadow? I would learne that,for by the markes of ſoueraintie, knowledge,
and reaſon, I ſhould bee ſalfe perſwaded I had daughters.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Which they,will make an obedient father.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Your name faire gentlewoman?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Come ſir, this admiration is much of the ſauour
of other your new prankes,I doe beſeech you
vnderſtand my purpoſes aright,
as you are old and reuerend,ſhould be wiſe,
here do you keepe a 100.Knights and Squires,
men ſo diſordred,ſo deboyſt and bold,
that this our court infeed with their manners,
ſhowes like a riotous Inne,epicuriſme,and luſt
make more like a tauerne or brothell,
then a great pallace, the ſhame it ſelfe doth ſpeake
for inſtant remedie,be thou deſired
by her,that elſe will take the thing ſheebegs,
a little to diſquantitie your traine,
and the remainder that ſhall ſtill depend,
to bee ſuch men as may beſort your age,
that know themſelues and you.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Darkenes,and Deuils!
ſaddle my horſes, call my traine together,
degenerate baſtard,ile not trouble thee,
yet haue I left a daughter.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: You ſtrike my people,and your diſordred rabble,
make ſeruants of their betters.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: We that too late repent’s,O ſir,are you cometis it your will that wee prepare any horſes,
ingratitude!thou marble harted ﬁend,more hideous when thou ſheweſt thee in a child,
then the Sea-monſter,
deteſted kite, thou lift
my traine, and men of choiſe and rareſt parts,
that all particulars of dutie knowe,
and in the moſt exa regard, ſupport
the worſhips of their name, O moſt ſmall fault,
how vgly did’ſt thou in Cordelia ſhewe,
that like an engine wrencht my frame of nature
from the ﬁxt place, drew from my heart all loue
and added to the gall,O Lear. Lear!
beat at this gate that let thy folly in,
and thy deere iudgement out,goe goe, my people?

speech.speaker: Duke,
speech.line: My Lord,I am giltles as I am ignorant.

speech.speaker: Leir.
speech.line: It may be ſo my Lord,
harke Nature,heare deere Goddeſſe,
ſuſpend thy purpoſe, if thou did’ſt intend
to make this creature fruitful
into her wombe, conuey ſterility,
drie vp in hir the organs of increaſe,
and from her derogate body neuer ſpring
a babe to honour her, if ſhee muſt teeme,
create her childe of ſpleene,that it may liue
and bee a thourt diſuetur’d torment to her,
let it ſtampe wrinckles in her brow of youth,
with accent teares, fret channels in her cheeks,
turne all her mothers paines and beneﬁts
to laughter and contempt, that ſhee may feele,
how ſharper then a ſerpents tooth it is,
to haue a thankleſſe child, goe,goe,my people?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Now Gods that we adore,
whereof comes this!

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Neuer aﬀli your ſelfe to know the cauſe,
but let his diſpoſition haue that ſcope that dotage giues it.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What, ﬁftie of my followers at a clap,
within a fortnight?

speech.speaker: Duke
speech.line: What is the matter ſir?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ile tell thee,
life and death!I am aſham’d
that thou haſt power to ſhake my manhood thus,
that theſe hot teares that breake from me perforce
ſhould make the worſt
blaſts and fogs vpon the
vntented woundings of a fatherscurſſe,
pierce euery ſence about the old fond eyes,
beweepe this cauſe againe, ile pluck you out,
& you caſt with the waters that you make to
temper clay, yea, I’ſt come to this?
yet I haue left a daughter,
whom I am ſure is kind and comfortable,
when ſhee ſhall heare this of thee, with her nailes
ſhee’l ﬂea thy woluiſh viſage, thou ſhalt ﬁnd
that ile reſume the ſhape,which thou doſt thinke
I haue caſt oﬀ for euer, thou ſhalt I warrant thee.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Doe you marke that my Lord?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I cannot be ſo partiall Gonerill
to the great loue I beare you.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Come ſir no more, you, more knaue then foole, after your maſter?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Nunckle Lear, Nunckle Lear,tary and take the foole with a fox
when one has caught her,
and ſuch a daughter
ഷhould ſure to the ſlaughter,
if my cap would buy a halter,
ſo the foole followes after.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: What Oſwald, ho.

speech.speaker: Oſwald.
speech.line: Here Madam.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: What haue you writ this letter to my ſiſter?

speech.speaker: Oſw.
speech.line: Yes Madam.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Take you ſome company, and away to horſe,
informe her full of my particular feares,
and thereto add ſuch reaſons of your owne,
as may compa it more,get you gon
& haſten your returne now my Lord,
this milkie gentlenes and courſe of yours
though I diſlike not, yet vnder pardon
y’are much more attaske for want of wiſedome,
then praise for harmefull mildnes.

speech.speaker: Duke
speech.line: How farre your eyes may pearce I cannot tell,
ſtriuing to better ought, we marre whats well.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Nay then.

speech.speaker: Duke
speech.line: Well,well,the euent,

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Goe you before to Gloſter with theſe letters,
acquaint my daughters no further with any thing you
know, then comes from her demand out of the letter,
if your diligence be not ſpeedie,I ſhall be there before you.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I will not ſleepe my Lord, till I haue deliuered
your letter.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: If a mans braines where in his heeles, wert not in
danger of kibes?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I boy.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Then I prethe be mery,thy wit ſhal nere goeſlipſhod

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ha ha ha.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Shaltſee thy other daughter will vſe thee kindly,
for though ſhees as like this,as a crab is like an
apple,yet I con,what I can tel.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why what canſt thou tell me boy?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Sheel taſt as like this,as a crab doth to a
crab, thou canſt not tell why ones noſe ſtande in the middle
of his face?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Why, to keep his eyes on either ſide’s noſe,
that what a man cannot ſmell out, a may ſpie into.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I did her wrong.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Canſt tell how an Oyſter makes his ſhell.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Nor I neither,but I can tell why a ſnayle has a houſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Why, to put his head in, not to giue it away to his
daughter,and leaue his hornes without a caſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I will forget my nature, ſo kind a father; be
my horſes readie?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Thy Aſſes are gone about them, the reaſon why
the ſeuen ſtarres are no more then ſeuen, is a prettie reaſon.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Becauſe they are not eight.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Yes thou wouldſt make a good foole.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: To tak’t againe perforce, Monſter, ingratitude!

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: If thou wert my foole Nunckle,id’e haue thee
beatē for being old before thy time.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Hows that?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Thou ſhouldſt not haue bin old, before thou hadſt
beenewiſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: O let me not be mad, not mad ſweet heauen!
I would not be mad, keepe me in temper,I would not be mad, are
the horſes readie?

speech.speaker: ſeruant
speech.line: Readie my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Come Boy.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Shee that is maide now,and laughs at my departure,
Shall not be a maide long,except things be cut ſhorter.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Saue thee Curan.

speech.speaker: Curan.
speech.line: And you Sir, I haue beene
with your father,and giuen him notice,
that the Duke of Cornwall and his Dutches
will bee here with him to night.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: How comes that?

speech.speaker: Curan.
speech.line: Nay,I know not,you haue heard of the newes abroad,
I meane the whiſperd ones, for there are yet but
eare-buſſing arguments.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Not, I pray you what are they?

speech.speaker: Curan.
speech.line: Haue you heard of no likely warres towards,
twixt the two Dukes of Cornwall and Albany?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Not a word.

speech.speaker: Curan.
speech.line: You may then in time,
fare you well ſir.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: The Duke be here to night! the better beſt,
this weaues it
ſelfe perforce into my buſines,
my father hath ſet gard to take my brother,
and I haue one thing of a queſie queſtion,
which muſt aske breefnes and fortune helpe;
brother, a word, diſcend brother I ſay,
my father watches, O flie this place,
intelligence is giuen where you are hid,
you haue now the good aduantage of the night,
haue you not ſpoken gainſt the Duke of Cornwall
ought,hee’s coming hether now in the night, it’h haſt,
and Regan with him, haue you nothing ſaid
vpon his partie againſt the Duke of Albany,
aduiſe your--

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I am ſure on’t not a word.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I heare my father coming,pardon me
in crauing,I muſt draw my ſword vpon you,
ſeeme to defend your ſelfe,
now quit you well,
yeeld, come before my father, light here, here,
flie brother flie, torches, torches, ſo farewell;
some bloud drawne on mee would beget opinion
of my more ﬁerce indeuour, I haue ſeene drunckards
doe more then this in ſport,father,father,
ſtop,ſtop, no,helpe?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Now Edmundwhere is the villaine?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Here ſtood he in the darke his ſharpe ſword out,
warbling of wicked charms, coniuring the Moone
to ſtand’s auſpicious Miſtris.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: But where is he?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Looke ſir, I bleed.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Where is the villaine Edmund?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Fled this way ſir, when by no meanes he could —

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Purſue him,go after,by no meanes, what?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Perſwade me to the murder of your Lordſhip,
but that I told him the reuengiue Gods,
gainſt Paracides did all their thunders bend,
ſpoke with how many ſould and ſtrong a bond
the child was bound to the father,ſir in ﬁne,
ſeeing how loathly oppoſite I ſtood,
to his vnnaturall purpoſe,with fell motion
with his prepared ſword,hee charges home
my vnprouided body, lancht mine arme,
but when he ſaw my beſt alarumd ſpirits,
bould in the quarrels,rights, rouſd to the encounter,
or whether gaſted by the noyſe I made,
but ſodainely he ﬂed.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Let him ﬂie farre,
not in this land ſhall hee remaine vncaught
and found, diſpatch, the noble Duke my maiſter,
my worthy Arch and Patron, comes to night,
by his authoritie I will proclaime it,
that he which ﬁnds him ſhall deſerue our thankes,
bringing the murderous caytiſe to the ſtake,
hee that conceals him,death.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: When I diſſwaded him from his intent,
and found him pight to doe it,with curſt ſpeech
I threatned to diſcouer him,he replyed,
thou vnpoſſeſſing Baſtard,doſt thou thinke,
if I would ſtand againſt thee, could the repoſure
of any truſt, vertue, or worth in thee
make thy words ſayth’d?no. what I ſhould denie.
as this I would,I,though thou didſt produce
my very charaer; id’e turne it all
to thy ſuggeſtion, plot, and damned pretence,
and thou muſt make a dullard of the world,
if they not thought the proﬁts of my death,
were very pregnant and potentiall ſpurres
to make thee ſeeke it.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Strong and faſtned villaine,
would he denie his letter, I neuer got him,
harke the Dukes trumpets,I know not why he comes,
all Ports ile barre, the villaine ſhall not ſcape,
the Duke muſt grant mee that, beſides, his piure
I will ſend farre and neere,that all the kingdome
may haue note of him, and of my land
loyall and naturall boy, ile worke the meanes
to make thee capable.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: How now my noble friend,ſince I came hether,
which I can call but now, I haue heard ſtrange newes.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: If it be true, all vengeance comes too ſhort
which can purſue the oﬀender, how doſt my Lord?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Madam my old heart is crackt, is crackt.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: What, did my fathers godſon ſeeke your life?
he whom my father named your Edgar?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I Ladie, Ladie, ſhame would haue it hid.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Was he not companion with the ryotous knights,
that tends vpon my father?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I know not Madam, tis too bad, too bad.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Yes Madam, he was.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: No maruaile then though he were ill aﬀeed,
Tis they haue put him on the old mans death,
To haue the waſt and ſpoyle of his reuenues:
I haue this preſent euening from my ſiſter,
Beene well inform’d of them,and with ſuch cautions,
That if they come to ſoiourne at my houſe,
ile not be there.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Nor I, aſſure thee Regan;
Edmund, I heard that you haue ſhewen your father
a child-like oﬃce.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Twas my dutie Sir.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: He did betray his praiſe, and receiued
This hurt you ſee, ſtriuing to apprehend him.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Is he purſued?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: If he be taken, he ſhall neuer more
be feard of doing harme,make your owne purpoſe
how in my ſtrength you pleaſe, for you Edmund,
whoſe vertue and obedience,doth this inſtant
so much commend it ſelfe, you ſhall bee ours,
natures of ſuch deepe truſt, wee ſhall much need
you,we ﬁrſt ſeaze on.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I ſhall ſerue you truly, how euer elſe.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: For him I thanke your grace.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: You know not why we came to viſit you?

speech.speaker: Regan.
speech.line: Thus out of ſeaſon, threatning darke ey’d night,
Ocaſions noble Gloſter of ſome poyſe,
Wherein we muſt haue vſe of your aduiſe,
Our Father he hath writ,ſo hath our ſiſter,
Of diferences, which I leſt thought it ﬁt,
To anſwer from our home,the ſeueral meſſengers
From hence attend diſpatch,our good old friend,
Lay comforts to your boſome,& beſtow your needfull councell
To our buſines,which craues the inſtant vſe.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I ſerue you Madam,
your Graces are right welcome.

speech.speaker: Steward.
speech.line: Good euen to thee friend, art of this houſe?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Where may we ſet our horſes?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: It’h mire.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Prethee if thou loue me, tell me.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I loue thee not.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Why then I care not for thee.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: If I had thee in Lipſburie pinfold, I would make
thee care for me.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Why doſt thou vſe me thus? I know thee not.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Fellow I know thee.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: What doſt thou know me for?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: A knaue, a raſcall,an eater of broken meates, a
baſe,proud,ſhallow,beggerly,three ſhewted hundred
pound,ﬁlthy worſted-ſtocken knaue, a lilly lyuer’d
aion taking knaue, a whorſon glaſſegazing ſuperﬁinicallrogue,
one truncke inheriting ſlaue, one that
would’ſt bee a baud in way of good ſeruice, and art nothing
būt the compoſition of a knaue, begger, coward,
pandar, and the ſonne and heire of a mungrell bitch,
whom I will beat into clamorous whyning, if thou
denie the leaſt ſillable of the addition.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: What a monſtrous fellow art thou, thus
to raile on one, that’s neither knowne of thee, nor
knowes thee.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: What a brazen fac’t varlet art thou, to deny
thou knoweſt mee,is it two dayes agoe ſince I beat thee,and tript vp thy
heeles before the King ? draw you rogue,
for though it be night the Moone ſhines,ile make a
ſop of the moon-ſhine a’you, draw you whorſon cullyonly
barber-munger, draw ?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Away, I haue nothing to doe with thee.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Draw you raſcall, you bring letters againſt
the King, and take Vanitie the puppets part, againſt
the royaltie of her father, draw you rogue or
ile ſo carbonado your ſhankes, draw you raſcall, come
your wayes.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Helpe, ho, murther, helpe.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Strike you ſlaue, ſtand rogue, ſtand you neate
ſlaue, ſtrike?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Helpe ho, murther, helpe.

scene.stagedir: Enter Edmund with his rapier drawne, Gloſter the Duke and Dutcheſſe.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: How now, whats the matter?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: With you goodman boy, if you pleaſe come,
ile ﬂeaſh you, come on yong maiſter.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Weapons,armes,whats the matter here?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Keepe peace vpon your liues, hee dies that ſtrikes
againe, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: The meſſengers from our ſiſter, and the King.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Whats is your diﬀerence, ſpeake?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I am ſcarſe in breath my Lord.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: No maruaile, you haue ſo beſtir’d your valour,
you cowardly raſcall, nature diſclaimes in thee, a Tayler
made thee.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Thou art a ſtrange fellow, a Taylor make a man.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I, a Tayler ſir; a Stone-cutter, or a Painter could
not haue made him ſo ill, though hee had beene but two
houres at the trade.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Speake yet, how grew your quarrell?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: This ancient ruﬃen ſir, whoſe life I haue ſpar’d
at ſute of his gray-beard.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Thou whorſon Zedd, thou vnneceſſarie letter,
my Lord, if you’l giue mee leaue, I will tread this vnboulted
villaine into morter, and daube the walles of a
iaques with him, ſpare my gray beard you wagtayle?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Peace ſir,
you beaſtly Knaue you haue no reuerence.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Yes ſir, but anger has a priuiledge.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Why art thou angry?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: That ſuch a ſlaue as this ſhould weare a ſword,
That weares no honeſty, ſuch ſmiling roges as theſe,
Like Rats oft bite thoſe cordes a twaine,
Which are to intrince, to vnlooſe ſmooth euery paſſion
That in the natures of their Lords rebell,
Bring oyle to ſtir, ſnow to their colder-moods,
Reneag aﬃrme, and turne their halcion beakes
With euery gale and varie of their maiſters,
Knowing nought like dayes but following,
a plague vpon your epeliptick Viſage,
ſmoyle you my ſpeeches, as I were a foole?
Gooſe and I had you vpon Sarum plaine,
Id’e ſend you cackling home to Camulet.,

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: What art thou mad old fellow?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: How fell you out, ſay that?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: No contraries hold more, antipathy,
Then I and ſuch a knaue.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Why doſt thou call him knaue,
what’s his offence.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: His countenance likes me not.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: No more perchance does mine,or his,or hers.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Sir tis my occupation to be plaine,
I haue ſeene better faces in my time
That ſtands on any ſhoulder that I ſee
Before me at this inſtant.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: This is a fellow
who hauing beene prayſd For bluntnes doth aﬀe
a ſawcy ruﬀines, And conſtraines the garb
quite from his nature, He cannot ﬂatter he,
he muſt be plaine, He muſt ſpeake truth,
and they will tak’t ſo, If not he’s plaine,
theſe kind of knaues I know Which in this plainnes
harbour more craft, And more corrupter ends,
then twentie ſilly ducking Obſeruants,
that ſtretch their duties niſely.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Sir in good ſooth, or in ſincere veritie,
Vnder the allowance of your graund aſpe,
Whoſe inﬂuence like the wreath of radient ﬁre
In ﬂickering Phœbus front.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: What mean’ſt thou by this?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: To goe out of my dialogue which you diſcommend
ſo much,I know ſir,I am no ﬂatterer,he that beguild
you in a plain accent, was a plaine knaue, which
for my part I will not bee, though I ſhould win your
diſpleaſure to intreat mee too’t.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: What’s the oﬀence you gaue him?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I neuer gaue him any,
it pleas’d the King his maiſter Very late
to ſtrike at me vpon his miſconſtruion,
When he coniun and ﬂattering his diſpleaſure
Tript me behind, being downe,inſulted, rayld,
And put vpon him ſuch a deale of man,
that, That worthied him, got prayſes of the King,
For him attempting who was ſelfe ſubdued,
And in the ﬂechuent of this dead exploit,
Drew on me here againe.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: None of theſe roges & cowards
but Alax is their foole.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Bring forth the ſtockes ho?
You ſtubburne miſereant knaue,you reuerent bragart,
Weele teach you.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I am too old to learne,
call not your ſtockes for me, I ſerue the King,
on whoſe imployments I was ſent to you,
You ſhould doe ſmall reſpe, ſhew too bold malice
Againſt the Grace and perſon of my maiſter,
Stopping his meſſenger.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Fetch forth the ſtockes?
as I haue life and honour, There ſhall he ſit till noone.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Till noone, till night my Lord,and all night too.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Why Madam, if I were your fathers dogge,
you could not vſe me ſo.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Sir being his knaue, I will.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: This is a fellow of the ſelfe ſame nature,
Our ſiſter ſpeake of,come bring away the ſtockes?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Let me beſeech your Grace not to doe ſo,
His fault is much,and the good King his maiſter VVill check him for’t,your
purpoſt low correion Is ſuch,as baſeſt and
remneſt wretches for pilfrings And moſt common treſpaſſes are puniſht with,
The King muſt take it ill, that hee’s ſo ſlightly valued In his meſſenger,
should haue him thus reſtrained.

speech.speaker: Duke
speech.line: Ile anſwer that.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: My ſiſter may receiue it much more worſe,
To haue her Gentleman abus’d, aſſalted
For following her aﬀaires,put in his legges,
Come my good Lord away?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I am ſorry for thee friend, tis the Dukes pleaſure,
VVhoſe diſpoſition all the world well knowes
VVill not be rubd nor ſtopt, ile intreat for thee.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Pray doe not ſir,I haue watcht and trauail’d hard,
Sometime I ſhall ſleepe ont, the reſt ile whiſtle,
A good mans fortune may grow out at heeles, hard,
Giue you good morrow.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: The Dukes to blame in this,
twill be ill tooke.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Good King that muſt approue the cômon ſaw,
Thou out of heauens benediion comſt
To the warme Sunne.
Approach thou beacon to this vnder gloabe,
That by thy comfortable beames I may
Peruſe this letter, nothing almoſt ſees my wracke
But miſerie, I know tis from Cordelia,
VVho hath moſt fortunately bin informed
Of my obſcured courſe, and ſhall ﬁnd time
From this enormious ſtate, ſeeking to giue
Loſſes their remedies, all wearie and ouerwatch
Take vantage heauie eyes not to behold
This ſhamefull lodging, Fortune goodnight,
Smile, once more turne thy wheele.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I heare my ſelfe proclaim’d,
And by the happie hollow of a tree
Eſcapt the hunt,no Port is free, no place
That guard, and moſt vnuſuall vigilence
Doſt not attend my taking while I may ſcape,
I will preſerue my ſelfe, and am bethought
To take the baſeſt and moſt pooreſt ſhape,
That euer penury in contempt of man,
Brought neare to beaſt, my face ile grime with ﬁlth,
Blanket my loynes, elſe all my haire in knots,
And with preſented nakednes outface,
The wind,and perſecution of the skie,
The Countrie giues me proofe and preſident
Of Bedlam beggers, who with roring voyces,
Strike in their numb’d and mortiﬁed bare armes,
Pins, wodden prickes,nayles,sprigs of roſemary,
And with this horrible obie from low ſeruice,
Poore pelting villages,ſheep-coates,and milles.
Sometime with lunaticke bans, ſometime with prayers
Enforce their charitie, poore Turlygod, poore Tom,
That’s ſomething yet, Edgar I nothing am.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Tis ſtrange that they ſhould ſo depart from hence,
And not ſend backe my meſſenger.

speech.speaker: Knight.
speech.line: As I learn’d,
the night before there was No purpoſe
of his remoue.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Hayle to thee noble maiſter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: How, mak’ſt thou this ſhame thy paſtime?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Ha ha, looke he weares crewell garters, Horſes are
tide by the heeles,dogges and beares Byt’h necke,
munkies bit’h loynes,and men Byt’h legges, when a mans
ouer luſty at legs, Then he weares wooden neatherſtockes.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Whats he,that hath ſo much thy place miſtooke
to ſet thee here?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: It is both he and ſhee,
your ſonne & daugter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No I ſay,

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I ſay yea.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No no,they would not.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Yes they haue.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: By Iupiter I ſweare no,
they durſt not do’t,
They would not, could not do’t,tis worſe then murder,
To doe vpon reſpe ſuch violent outrage,
Reſolue me with all modeſt haſt, which way
Thou may’ſt deſerue,or they purpoſe this vſage,
Coming from vs.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: My Lord, when at their home
I did commend your highnes letters to them,
Ere I was riſen from the place that ſhewed
My dutie kneeling, came there a reeking Poſt,
Stewd in his haſt,halfe breathles,panting forth
From Gonerill his miſtris, ſalutations,
Deliuered letters ſpite of intermiſſion,
Which preſently they read, on whoſe contents
They ſummond vp their men, ſtraight tooke horſe,
Commanded me to follow,and attend
the leaſure Of their anſwere, gaue me cold lookes,
And meeting here the other meſſenger,
Whoſe welcome I perceau’d had poyſon’d mine,
Being the very fellow that of late
Diſplay’d ſo ſawcily againſt your Highnes,
Hauing more man then wit about me drew,
He raiſed the houſe with loud and coward cries,
Your ſonne and daughter found this treſpaſ worth
This ſhame which here it ſuﬀers.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: O how this mother ſwels vp toward my hart,
Hiſterica paſſio downe thou climing ſorrow,
Thy element’s below, where is this daughter?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: With the Earle ſir within,

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Follow me not, ſtay there?

speech.speaker: Knight.
speech.line: Made you no more oﬀēce
then what you ſpeake of?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: No,
how chance the King comes with ſo ſmall a traine?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: And thou hadſt beene ſet in the ſtockes for that
queſtion,thou ha’dſt well deſerued it.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Why Foole?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Weele ſet thee to ſchoole to an Ant,to teach
thee ther’s no labouring in the winter,all that follow their
noſes,are led by their eyes, but blind men, and ther’s
not a noſe among a 100,but can ſmell him thats ſtinking,
let goe thy hold when a great wheele runs downe a
hill. leaſt it breake thy necke with following it,but the
great one that goes vp the hill, let him draw thee after,
when a wiſe man giues thee better councell,giue mee mine
againe, I would haue none but knaues follow it, ſince a
foole giues it.
That Sir that ſerues for gaine,
And followes but for forme:
Will packe when it begin to raine,
And leaue thee in the ſtorme,
But I will tarie, the foole will ſtay,
And let the wiſe man ﬂie:
The knaue turnes foole that runs away,
The foole no knaue perdy.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Where learnt you this foole?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Not in the ſtockes.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Denie to ſpeake with mee,
th’are ſicke, th’are weary,
They traueled hard to night, meare Iuſtice,
I the Images of reuolt and ﬂying oﬀ,
Fetch mee a better anſwere.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: My deere Lord,
you know the ﬁerie qualitie of the Duke,
how vnremoueable and ﬁxt he is
in his owne Courſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Vengeance, death,plague,confuſion,
what ﬁerie quality, why Gloſter, Gloſter,
id’e ſpeake with the Duke of Cornewall, and his wife.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: The King would ſpeake with Cornewal,
the deare father
Would with his daughter ſpeake,commands her ſeruice,
ﬁerie Duke, tell the hot Duke thatLear,
No but not yet may be he is not well,
Inﬁrmitie doth ſtill negle all oﬃce,
where to our health Is boud,we are not our ſelues,
when nature being opreſt Cômand the mind
to ſuﬀer with the bodie ile forbeare,
And am fallen out with my more hedier will,
To take the indiſpos’d and ſickly ﬁt,
for the ſound man, Death on my ſtate, wherfore
ſhould he ſit here? This a perſwades me,
that this remotion of the Duke & her
Is praiſe,only giue me my ſeruant forth,
Tell the Duke and’s wife, Ile ſpeake with them
Now preſently, bid them come forth and heare me,
Or at their chamber doore ile beate the drum,
Till it cry ſleepe to death.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I would haue all well betwixt you.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Oh my heart,my heart.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Cry to it Nunckle,as the Cockney did to the
eeles,when ſhe put vm it’h pâſt aliue,ſhe rapt vm
ath coxcombs with a ſtick, and cryed downe wantons
downe,twas her brother,that in pure kindnes to his
horſe buttered his hay.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Good morrow to you both.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Hayle to your Grace.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I am glad to ſee your highnes.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Regan I thinke you are,I know what reaſon
I haue to thinke ſo,if thou ſhouldſt not be glad,
I would diuorſe me from thy mothers tombe
Sepulchring an adultreſſe. yea are you free?
Some other time for that. Beloued Regan,
Thy ſiſter is naught, oh Regan ſhe hath tyed,
Sharpe tooth’d vnkindnes,like a vulture heare,
I can ſcarce ſpeake to thee, thout not beleeue,
Of how depriued a qualitie, O Regan,

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I pray ſir take patience, I haue hope
You leſſe know how to value her deſert,
Then ſhe to ſlacke her dutie.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: My curſſes on her.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: O Sir, you are old,
Nature on you ſtandes on the very verge
of her conﬁne, You ſhould be rul’d and led
by ſome diſcretion, That diſcernes your ſtate
better thē you your ſelfe, Therfore I pray that
to our ſiſter,you do make returne,
Say you haue wrong’d her Sir?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Aske her forgiuenes,
Doe you marke how this becomes the houſe,
Deare daughter, I confeſſe that I am old,
Age is vnneceſſarie,on my knees I beg,
That you’l vouchſafe me rayment,bed and food.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Good ſir no more, theſe are vnſightly tricks,
Returne you to my ſiſter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No Regan,
She hath abated me of halfe my traine,
Lookt blacke vpon me, ſtrooke mee with her tongue
Moſt Serpent-like vpon the very heart,
All the ſtor’d vengeances of heauen fall
on her ingratful top, Strike her yong bones,
you taking ayrs with lamenes.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: ﬁé ﬁe ſir.
You nimble lightnings dart your blinding ﬂames,
Into her ſcornfull eyes, infe her beautie,
You Fen ſuckt fogs, drawne by the powrefull Sunne,
To fall and blaſt her pride.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: O the bleſt Gods,
ſo will you wiſh on me, When the raſh moode.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No Regan, thou ſhalt neuer haue my curſe,
The tēder hefted nature ſhall not giue
the or’e To harſhnes,her eies are ﬁerce,but thine
do cഅfort & not burne Tis not in thee
to grudge my pleaſures, to cut oﬀ my traine,
To bandy haſty words,to ſcant my ſizes,
And in concluſion,to oppoſe the bolt
Againſt my coming in, thou better knoweſt,
The oﬃces of nature, bond of child-hood,
Eﬀes of curteſie, dues of gratitude,
Thy halfe of the kingdome, haſt thou not forgot
Wherein I thee indow’d.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Good ſir too’th purpoſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Who put my man i’th ſtockes?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: What trumpets that?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I know’t my ſiſters,this approues her letters,
That ſhe would ſoone be heere,is your Lady come?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: This is a ſlaue, whoſe eaſie borrowed pride
Dwels in the fickle grace of her, a followes.
Out varlet,from my ſight.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: What meanes your Grace?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Who ſtuck my seruant,Regan I haue good hope
Thou didſt not know ant.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Who comes here? O heauens!
If you do loue old men, if your ſweet ſway
allow Obedience,if your ſelues are old,
make it your cauſe, Send downe and take my part,
Art not aſham’d to looke vpon this beard?
O Regan wilt thou take her by the hand?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Why not by the hand ſir, how haue I oﬀended?
Als not oﬀence that indiſcretion ﬁnds,
And dotage tearmes ſo.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: O ſides you are too tough,
Will you yet hold?
how came my man it’h ſtockes?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I ſet him there ſir, but his owne diſorders
Deſeru’d much leſſe aduancement.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: You,did you?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I pray you father being weake ſeeme ſo,
If till the expiration of your moneth,
You will returne and ſoiorne with my ſiſter,
Diſmiſſing halfe your traine, come then to me,
I am now from home,and out of that prouiſion,
Which ſhall be needful for your entertainment.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Returne to her,and ﬁftie men diſmiſt,
No rather I abiure all roofes, and chuſe
To wage againſt the enmitie of the Ayre,
To be a Comrade with the Woolfe and owle,
Neceſſities ſharpe pinch, returne with her,
Why the hot bloud in France, that dowerles Tooke
our yongeſt borne, I could as well be brought
To knee his throne,and Squire-like penſion bag,
To keepe baſe life afoot,returne with her,
Perſwade me rather to be ſlaue and ſumter
To this deteſted groome.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: At your choiſe ſir.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Now I prithee daughter do not make me mad,
I will not trouble thee my child,farewell,
Wee’le no more meete, no more ſee one another.
But yet thou art my ﬂeſh, my bloud,my daughter,
Or rather a diſeaſe that lies within my ﬂeſh,
Which I muſt needs call mine,thou art a bile,
A plague ſore,an imboſſed carbuncle
in my Corrupted bloud,but Ile not chide thee,
Let ſhame come when it will,I doe not call it,
I doe not bid the thunder bearer ſhoots,
Nor tell tailes of thee to high Iudging Ioue,
Mend when thou canſt,be better at thy leaſure,
I can be patient,I can ſtay with Regan,
I and my hundred Knights.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Not altogether ſo ſir,
I looke not for you yet, Nor am prouided
for your fit welcome, Giue eare ſir to my ſiſter,
for thoſe That mingle reaſon with your paſſion,
Muſt be content to thinke you are old,andſo,
But ſhe knowes what ſhee does.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Is this well ſpoken now?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I dare auouch it ſir, what ﬁftie followers,
Is it not well,what ſhould you need of more,
Yea or ſo many, ſith that both charge and danger
Speakes gainſt ſo great a number, how in a houſe
Should many people vnder two commands
Hold amytie, tis hard,almoſt impoſſible.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Why might not you my Lord receiue attendace
From thoſe that ſhe cals ſeruants, or from mine?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Why not my Lord?
if then they chanc’ſt to ſlacke you,
We could controwle them,if you will come to me,
For now I ſpie a danger,I intreat you,
To bring but ﬁue and twentie, to no more
Will I giue place or notice,

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I gaue you all.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: And in good time you gaue it.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Made you my guardians, my depoſitaries,
But kept a reſeruation to be followed
With ſuch a number, what, muſt I come to you
With ﬁue and twentie, Regan ſaid you ſo?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: And ſpeak’t againe my Lord,no more with me.

speech.speaker: Lea.
speech.line: Thoſe wicked creatures yet do ſeem wel fauor’d
When others are more wicked,not being the worſt
Stands in ſome ranke of prayſe,Ile goe with thee,
Thy ﬁfty yet doth double ﬁue and twentie,
And thou art twice her loue.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Heare me my Lord,
What need you ﬁue and twentie, tenne, or ﬁue,
To follow in a houſe, where twiſe ſo many
Haue a commaund to tend you.

speech.speaker: Regan.
speech.line: What needes one?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: O reaſon not the deed, our baſeſt beggers,
Are in the pooreſt thing ſuperﬂuous,
Allow not nature more then nature needes,
Mans life is cheape as beaſts,thou art a Lady,
If onely to goe warme were gorgeous,
Why nature needes not,what thou gorgeous weareſt
Which ſcarcely keepes thee warme, but for true need,
You heauens giue me that patience,patience I need,
You ſee me here (you Gods) a poore old fellow,
As full of greefe as age,wretched in both,
If it be you that ſtirres theſe daughters hearts
Againſt their Father, foole me not to much,
To beare it lamely, touch me with noble anger,
O let not womens weapons,water drops
Stayne my mans cheekes. no you vnnaturall hags,
I will haue ſuch reuenges on you both,
That all the world ſhall, I will doe ſuch things,
What they are yet I know not, but they ſhalbe
The’terrors of the earth, you thinke ile weepe,
No ile not weepe, I haue full cauſe of weeping,
But this heart ſhall breake,in a 100 thouſand ﬂowes
Or ere ile weepe, O foole I ſhall goe mad.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Let vs withdraw, twill be a ſtorme.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: This houſe is little the old man and his people,
Cannot be well beſtowed.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Tis his owne blame hath put himſelfe from reſt,
And muſt needs taſt his folly.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: For his particular, ile receiue him gladly,
But not one follower.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: So am I puspos’d,
where is my Lord of Gloſter?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Followed the old man forth,he is return’d.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: The King is in high rage, & wil I know not whether.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Tis good to giue him way,he leads himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: My Lord,intreat him by no meanes to ſtay.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Alack the night comes on,and the bleak winds
Do ſorely ruﬀel,for many miles about
ther’s not a buſh.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: O ſir, to wilfull men
The iniuries that they themſelues procure,
Muſt be their ſchoolemaſters,ſhut vp your doores,
He is attended with a deſperate traine,
And what they may incenſe him to,being apt,
To haue his eare abuſd, wiſedome bids feare.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Shut vp your doores my Lord,tis a wild night,
My Reg counſails well,come out at’h ſtorme.

scene.stagedir: Enter Kent and a Gentleman at ſeuerall doores.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Whats there beſide foule weather?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: One minded like the weather moſt vnquietly.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I know you, whers the King?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Contending with the fretfull element, Bids the wind blow the earth into the ſea, Or ſwell the curled waters boue the maine That things might change or ceaſe,
teares his white haire, Which the impetvous blaſts with eyles rage Catch in their furie, and make nothing of,
Striues’ in his little world of man to outſcorne, The too and fro conﬂiing wind and raine, This night wherin the cub-drawne Beare would couch,
The Lyon,and the belly pinched Wolfe Keepe their furre dry,vnbonneted he runnes, And bids what will take all.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: But who is with him?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: None but the foole,who labours to out-ieſt
His heart ſtrooke iniuries.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Sir I doe know you,
And dare vpon the warrant of my Arte,
Commend a deare thing to you,there is diuiſion.
Although as yet the face of it be couer’d,
With mutuall cunning, twixt Albany and Cornwall
But true it is, from France there comes a power Into this ſcattered kingdome, who alreadie wiſe in our negligẽce,
Have ſecret feet in ſome of our beſt Ports, And are at point to ſhew their open banner.
Now to you,if on my credit you dare build ſo ſarre,To make your ſpeed to Douer, you ſhall find
Some that will thanke you, making iuſt report
Of how vnnaturall and bemadding ſorrow
The King hath cauſe to plaine.
I am a Gentleman of blood and breeding,
And from ſome knowledge and aſſurance, Oﬀer this oﬃce to you.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: I will talke farther with you.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: No doe not,
For conﬁrmation that I much more
Then my out-wall, open this purſe and take
VVhat it containes, if you ſhall ſee Cordelia,
