As feare not but you ſhall, ſhew her this ring,
And ſhe will tell you who your fellow is,
That yet you doe not know, ﬁe on this ſtorme,
I will goe ſeeke the King.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Giue me your hand,
haue you no more to ſay?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Few words but to eﬀe more then all yet:
That when we haue found the King. Ile this way,you
that,he that ﬁrſt lights
On him,hollow the other.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Blow wind & cracke your cheekes,rage,blow
You catarickes,& Hiricanios ſpout
til you haue drencht, The ſteeples drown’d the cockes,
you ſulpherous and Thought executing fires,
vaunt-currers to Oke-cleaning thunderboults,
ſinge my white head, And thou all ſhaking thunder,
ſmite ﬂat The thicke Rotunditie of the world,
cracke natures Mold,all Germains ſpill at once
that make Ingratefull man.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: O Nunckle, Court holy water in a drie houſe Is
better then this raine water out a doore, Good Nunckle
in,and aske thy daughters bleſſing, Heers a night pities
nether wiſe man nor foole.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Rumble thy belly full, ſpit fire, ſpout raine,
Nor raine,wind,thunder,fire,are my daughters,
I taske not you you elements with vnkindnes,
I neuer gaue you kingdome, cald you children,
You owe me no ſubſcription,why thenlet fall
your horrible pleſure Here I ſtād your ſlaue,
a poore inﬁrme weak & Deſpis’d ould man,
but yet I call you ſeruile Miniſters,
that haue with a pernitious daughters ioin’d
Your high engēdred batrel gainſt a head
ſo old & white As this, O tis foule.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Hee that has a houſe to put his head in, has a good
headpeece,
the Codpeece that will houſe before the head, has any
the head and hee ſhall lowſe, ſo beggers mary many,
the man that makes his toe, what hee his heart ſhould make,
ſhall haue a corne cry woe, and turne his ſleepe to wake,
for there was neuer yet faire woman but ſhee made
mouthes in a glaſſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No I will be the patterne of all patience
I will ſay nothing.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Whoſse there?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Marry heers Grace, & a codpis, that’s a
wiſeman and a foole.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Alas ſir,ſit you here? Things that loue night,
loue not ſuch nights as theſe, The wrathfull Skies
gallow,the very wanderer of the Darke,
and makes them keepe their caues, Since I was man,
ſuch ſheets of fire, Such burſts of horred thunder,
ſuch grones of Roaring winde,and rayne, I ne’re
remember To haue heard, mans nature cannot cary
The aﬀliion, nor the force.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Let the great Gods
that keepe this dreadful Powther ore our heades,
find out their enemies now, Tremble thou wretch
that haſt within thee Vndivulged crimes,
vnwhipt of Iuſtice, Hide thee thou bloudyhand,
thou periur’d,and Thou ſimular man of vertue
that art inceſtious, Caytiſe in peeces ſhake,
that vnder couert And conuenient ſeeming,
haſt praiſed on mans life, Cloſe’pent vp guilts,
riue your concealed centers, And cry
theſe dreadfull ſummoners grace, I am a man
more find againſt their ſinning.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Alacke bare headed,
gracious my Lord,hard by here is a houell,
ſome friendſhip will it lend you gainſt the tempeſt,
repoſe you there, whilſt I to this hard houſe,
more hard then is the ſtone whereof tis rais’d,
which euen but now demaunding after me,
denide me to come in,returne and force
their ſcanted curteſie.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: My wit begins to turne,
Come on my boy, how doſt my boy, art cold?
I am cold my ſelfe, where is this ſtraw my fellow,
The art of our neceſſities is ſtrange
that can, Make vild things precious, come you houell
poore, Foole and knaue,I haue one part of my heart;
That ſorrowes yet for thee.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Hee that has a little tine witte,
with hey ho the wind and the raine,
muſt make content with his fortunes ﬁt,
for the raine, it raineth euery day.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: True my good boy, come bring vs to this houell?

scene.stagedir: Enter Gloſter and the Baſtard with lights.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Alacke alacke Edmund, I like not this, Vnnaturall
dealing when I deſir’d their leaue That I might pitty him,
they tooke from me The vſe of mine owne houſe, charg’d
me on paine Of their diſpleaſure, neither to ſpeake
of him, Intreat for him, not any way ſuſtaine him.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Moſt ſauage and vnnaturall.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Go toe ſay you nothing,ther’s a diuiſiō betwixt
the Dukes, And a worſe matter then that, I haue
receiued A letter this night, tis dangerous to be ſpoken,
I haue lockt the letter in my cloſet, theſe iniuries The
King now beares, will be reuenged home Ther’s part of
a power already landed, We muſt incline to the King, I
will ſeeke him, and Priuily releeue him, goe you and
maintaine talke With the Duke, that my charity be not of
him Perceiued, if hee aske for me, I am ill,and gon To
bed, though I die for’t,as no leſſe is threatned me, The King
my old maſter muſt be releeued,there is Some ſtrāge thing
toward, Edmund pray you be careful.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: This curteſie forbid thee,ſhal the Duke
inſtāly know And of that letter to,
this ſeems a faire deſeruing And muſt draw me
that which my father looſes, no leſſe Then all,
then yonger riſes when the old doe fall.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Here is the place my Lord, good my Lord enter,
the tyrannie of the open nights too ruﬀe
for nature to indure.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Let me alone.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Good my Lord enter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Wilt breake my heart?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I had rather breake mine owne,
good my Lord enter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Thou think’ſt tis much, that this tempeſtious ſtorme
Inuades vs to the skin, ſo tis to thee,
But where the greater malady is ﬁxt
The leſſer is ſcarce felt, thoud’ſt ſhun a Beare,
But if thy ﬂight lay toward the roring ſea,
Thoud’ſt meet the beare it’h mouth, whē the mind’s free
The bodies delicate, this tempeſt in my mind
Doth from my ſences take all feeling elſe
Saue what beates their filiall ingratitude,
Is it not as this mouth ſhould teare this hand
For lifting food to’t, but I will puniſh ſure,
No I will weepe no more, in ſuch a night as this?
O Regan, Gonorill,
your old kind father, Whoſe franke heart gaue you all,
O that way madnes lies, Let me ſhun that,
no more of that.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Good my Lord enter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Prethe goe in thy ſelfe, ſeeke thy one eaſe
This tempeſt will not giue me leaue to ponder
On things would hurt me more, but ile goe in,
Poore naked wretches, where ſo ere you are
That bide the pelting of this pittiles night,
How ſhall your houſe-leſſe heads, and vnfed ſides,
Your loopt and windowed raggednes defend you
From ſeaſons ſuch as theſe, O I haue tane
Too little care of this,take phyſicke, pompe,
Expoſe thy ſelfe to feele what wretches feele,
That thou mayſt ſhake the ſuperﬂux to them,
And ſhew the heauens more iuſt.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Come not in here Nunckle,her’s a ſpirit,helpe
me,helpe mee.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Giue my thy hand, whoſe there.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: A ſpirit, he ſayes, his nam’s poore
Tom.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: What art thou that doſt grumble there in the
ſtraw, come forth?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Away,the fowle ﬁend followes me, thorough the
ſharpe hathorne blowes the cold wind, goe to thy
bed and warme thee.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Haſt thou giuen all to thy daughters,and art
thou come to this?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Who giues any thing to poore Tom, whome
the foule ﬁend hath led, through fire, and through foord,
and whirli-poole, ore bog and quagmire
that has layd kniues vnder his pillow,and halters
in his pue,ſet ratsbane by his porrage, made him
proud of heart, to ride on a bay trotting horſe ouer foure
incht bridges, to courſe his owne ſhadow for a traytor,
bleſſe thy ﬁue wits, Toms a cold,
bleſſe thee from whirle-winds, starre-bluſting,and taking,
doe poore Tom ſome charitie, whom the foule ﬁend
vexes,there could I haue him now,and there,
and there againe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What, his daughters brought him to this paſſe,
Couldſt thou ſaue nothing, didſt thou giue them all?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Nay he reſeru’d a blanket, elſe we had beene all
ſham’d.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Now all the plagues that in the pendulous ayre
Hang fated ore mens faults, fall on thy daughters.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: He hath no daughters ſir.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Death traytor, nothing could haue ſubdued nature
To ſuch a lownes, but his vnkind daughters,
Is it the faſhion that diſcarded fathers,
Should haue thus little mercy on their ﬂeſh,
Iudicious puniſhment twas this ﬂeſh Begot
thoſe Pelicane daughters.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Pilicock ſate on pelicocks hill, a lo lo lo.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: This cold night will turne vs all to fooles &
madmen.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Take heede at’h foule ﬁend, obay thy parents,
keep thy words iuſtly, ſweare not, commit not
with mans ſworne ſpouſe, ſet not thy ſweet heart on
proud array, Toms a cold,

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What haſt thou beene?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: A Seruingman, proud in heart and mind, that
curld my haire, wore gloues in my cap, ſerued the luſt
of my miſtris heart, and did the a of darkenes with
her, ſwore as many oathes as I ſpake words,and broke
them in the ſweet face of heauen, one that ſlept in the
contriuing of luſt, and wakt to doe it, wine loued I
deeply, dice deerely, and in woman out paromord
the Turke, falſe of heart,light of care,bloudie of hand,
Hog in ſlock, Fox in ſtealth, VVoolfe in greedines,, Dog
in madnes, Lyon in pray, let not the creeking of ſhooes,
nor the ruſlngs of ſilkes betray thy poore heart to women,
keepe thy foote out of brothell, thy hand out of
placket, thy pen from lenders booke, and defie the
foule ﬁend,ſtill through the hathorne blowes the
cold wind, hay no on ny. Dolphin my boy,
my boy, caeſe let him trot by.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why thou wert better in a graue, then to anſwere
with thy vncouered bodie this extremitie of the skies,is
man no more, but this cōﬁder him well, thou oweſt
the worme no ſilke, the beaſt no hide, the ſheepe no
wooll, the cat no perfume, her’s three ons are
ſo phiſticated,thou art the thing it ſelfe, vnaccomodated
man, is no more but ſuch a poore bare forked Animall
as thou art, oﬀ oﬀ you lendings,
come on.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Prithe Nunckle be content, this is a naughty
night to ſwim in,now a little ﬁre in a wild field,
were like an old leachers heart, a ſmall ſparke,all the reſt
in bodie cold,looke here comes a walking ﬁre.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: This is the foule ﬁend fliberdigibek, hee begins at
curphew, and walks till the ﬁrſt cocke, he giues the web,
& the pin, ſquemes the eye, and makes the hare lip,
mildewes the white wheate, and hurts the poore creature of earth,
ſwithald footed thrice the old,
he met the night mare and her nine fold
bid her,O-light and her troth plight
and arint thee, witch arint thee.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: How fares your Grace?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Whats hee?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Whoſe there, what i’ſt you ſeeke?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: What are you there? your names?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Poore Tom, that eats the ſwimming frog, the
tode,the tod pole, the wall-newt, and the water, that
in the furie of his heart,when the foule ﬁend rages,eats
cow-dung for fallets,ſwallowes the old ratt, and the
ditch dogge,drinkes the greene mantle of the ſtanding
poole, who is whipt from tithing to tithing, and
ſtock-puniſht and impriſoned, who hath had three ſutes
to his backe, ſixe ſhirts to his bodie,
horſe to ride, and weapon to weare.
But miſe and rats,and ſuch ſmall Deere,
Hath beene Toms foode for ſeuen long yeare
Beware my follower, peace ſnulbug, peace thou ﬁend.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: What hath your Grace no better company?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: The Prince of darkenes is a Gentleman, modo
he’s caled and ma hu.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Our ﬂeſh and bloud is growne ſo
vilde my Lord, that it doth hate what gets it.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Poore Tom a cold.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Go in with me,my dutie cānot ſuﬀer
to obay in all your daughters hard commaunds,
though their iniunion be to barre my doores,
and let this tyranous night take hold vpon you,
yet haue I venter’d to come ſeeke you out,
and bring you where both food and ﬁre is readie.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: ﬁrſt let me talke with this Philoſopher,
What is the cauſe of thunder?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: My good Lord take his oﬀer,
goe into the houſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ile talke a word with this moſt learned Theban,
what is your ſtudie?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: How to preuent the ﬁend, and to kill vermine.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Let me aske you one word in priuate.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Importune him to goe my Lord,
his wits begin to vnſettle.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Canſt thou blame him,
His daughters ſeeke his death, O that good Kent,
He ſaid it would be thus, poore baniſht man,
Thou ſayeſt the King growes mad, ile tell thee friend
I am almoſt mad my ſelfe,I had a ſonne
Now out-lawed from my bloud,a ſought my life
But lately, very late, I lou’d him friend
No father his ſonne deerer, true to tell thee,
The greefe hath craz’d my wits, What a nights this?
I doe beſeech your Grace.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: O crie you mercie
noble Philoſopher,your company.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Toms a cold.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: In fellow there, in’t houell keepe thee warme.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Come lets in all.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: This way my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: With him
I wil keepe ſtil, with my Philoſopher.

speech.speaker: Ken.
speech.line: Good my Lord ſooth him,
let him take the fellow.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Take him you on.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Sirah come on, goe along with vs?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Come good Athenian.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: No words,no words, huſh.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Child Rowland, to the darke towne come,
His word was ſtill fy fo and fum,
I ſmell the bloud of a Britiſh man.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: I will haue my reuenge ere I depart the houſe.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: How my Lord I may be cenſured,that nature
thus giues way to loyaltie,ſome thing feares me to
thinke of.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: I now perceiue it was not altogether your
brothers euill diſpoſition made him ſeeke his death,but
a prouoking merit, ſet a worke by a reproueable badnes
in himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: How malicious is my fortune, that I muſt repent
to bee iuſt? this is the letter he ſpoke of,
which approues him an intelligent partie to the aduantages
of France, O heauens that this treaſon were, or not
I the deteer.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Goe with me to the Dutches.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: If the matter of this paper be certaine, you haue
mighty buſines in hand.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: True or falſe, it hath made thee Earle of Gloſter,
ſeeke out where thy father is, that hee may bee
readie for our apprehenſion.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: If I ﬁnd him comforting the King, it will ſtuﬀe
his ſuſpition more fully, I will perſeuere in my courſe of
loyaltie, though the conﬂi be ſore betweene that and
my bloud.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: I will lay truſt vpon thee, and thou ſhalt ﬁnd
a dearer father in my loue.

scene.stagedir: Enter Gloſter and Lear,Kent, Foole, and Tom.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Here is better then the open ayre, take it thankfully,
I will peece out the comfort with what addition I
can,I will not be long from you.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: All the power of his wits haue giuen way to
impatience, the Gods deſerue your kindnes.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Fretereto cals me, and tels me Nero is an angler
in the lake of darknes,pray innocent beware
the foule ﬁend.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Prithe Nunckle tell me, whether a mad man be
a Gentleman or a Yeoman.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: A King, a King, to haue a thouſand with red burning ſpits come hiſzing in vpon them.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: The foule ﬁend bites my backe.

speech.speaker: Foole
speech.line: He’s mad, that truſts in the tamenes of a Wolfe,a horſes health,
a boyes loue, or a whores oath.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: It ſhalbe be done, I wil arraigne them ſtraight,
Come ſit thou here moſt learned Iuſtice
Thou ſapient ſir ſit here, no you ſhee Foxes —

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Looke where he ſtands and glars, wanſt thou eyes, at tral madam come ore the broome Beſſy to mee.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Her boat hath a leake, and ſhe muſt not ſpeake,
Why ſhe dares not come,ouer to thee.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: The foule ﬁend haūts poore Tom in the voyee of a nightingale Hoppedance cries in Toms belly
for two white herring, Croke not blacke Angell, I haue no foode for thee.

speech.speaker: Kent
speech.line: How doe you ſir? ſtand you not ſo amazd, will you lie downe and reſt vpon the cuſhings?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: He ſee their triall ﬁrſt, bring in their euidence, thou robbed man of Iuſtice take thy place, & thou
his yokefellow of equity, bench by his ſide, you are ot’h commiſſion, ſit you too.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Let vs deale iuſtly ſleepeſt or wakeſt thou iolly ſhepheard, Thy ſheepe bee in the corne, and for one
blaſt of thy minikin mouth,thy ſheepe ſhall take no harme, Pur the cat is gray.

speech.speaker: Lear
speech.line: Arraigne her ﬁrſt tis Gonoril, I here take my oath before this honorable aſſembly kickt the poore king her father.

speech.speaker: Foole
speech.line: Come hither miſtriſſe is your name Gonorill.

speech.speaker: Lear
speech.line: She cannot deny it.

speech.speaker: Foole
speech.line: Cry you mercy I tooke you for a ioyne ſtoole.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: And heres another whoſe warpt lookes proclaime, What ſtore her hart is made an ſtop here there,
Armes,armes,ſword,ﬁre,corruption in the place,Falſe Iuſticer why haſt thou let her ſcape.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Bleſſe thy fiue wits

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: O pity ſir,where is the patience now,That you ſo oft haue boaſted to retaine.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: My teares begin to take his part ſo much. Theile marre my counterfeiting.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: The little dogs and all Trey, Blanch, and Sweet hart, ſee they barke at me.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Tom will throw his head at them, auaunt you
curs, Be thy mouth, or blacke, or white,
tooth that poyſons if it bite,
Maſtife,grayhoūd,mungril,grim-hoūd
or ſpaniel,brach or him,
Bobtaile tike,or trūdletaile,
Tom will make them weep & waile,
For with throwing thus my head,
dogs leape the hatch and all are ﬂed,
loudla doodla come march to wakes, and faires,
and market townes, poore Tom thy horne is dry.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Then let them anotomize Regan, ſee what
breeds about her Hart is there any cauſe in nature that
makes this hardnes, You ſir, I entertaine you for one of
my hundred, Only I do not like the faſhion of your garments
youle ſay, They are Perſian attire, but let them be
chang’d.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Now good my Lord lie here awhile.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Make no noiſe,make no noiſe,draw the curtains,
ſo,ſo,ſo. Weele go to ſupper it’h morning,ſo,ſo,ſo.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Come hither friend,
where is the King my maiſter.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Here ſir, but trouble him not his wits are gon.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Good friend I prithy take him in thy armes,
I haue or’e heard a plot of death vpon him,
There is a Litter ready lay him in’t,
& driue towards Douer frend, Where thou ſhalt meet
both welcome & proteion,take vp thy maſter,
If thou ſhould’ſt dally halfe an houre,his life
with thine And all that oﬀer to defend him
ſtand in aſſured loſſe, Take vp the King
and followe me, that will to ſome prouiſion
Giue thee quicke condu.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Oppreſſed nature ſleepes,
This reſt might yet haue balmed thy broken ﬁnewes,
Which if convenience will not alow ſtand in hard cure,
Come helpe to beare thy maiſter, thou muſt not ſtay behind.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Come,come away.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: When we our betters ſee bearing our woes:we ſcarcely thinke, our miſeries,our foes. Who alone ſuﬀers ſuﬀers,moſt it’h mind,
Leauing free things and happy ſhowes behind,But then the mind much ſuﬀerance doth or’e ſcip,When griefe hath mates,and bearing fellowſhip:
How light and portable my paine ſeemes now,When that which makes me bend, makes the King bow. He childed as I fathered,Tom away,
Marke the high noyſes and thy ſelfe bewray, When ſalfe opinion whoſe wrong thoughts defile thee,In thy iuſt proofe repeals and reconciles thee,
What will hap more to night,ſafe ſcape the King, Lurke,lurke.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Poſt ſpeedily to my Lord your husband ſhew
him this letter The army of France is landed,ſeeke out
the vilaine Gloſter.

speech.speaker: Regan.
speech.line: Hang him inſtantly.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Plucke out his eyes.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Leaue him to my diſpleaſure,Edmūd keep
you our ſiſter company. The reuenge we are bound to
take vpon your trayterous father, Are not ﬁt for your
beholding, aduiſe the Duke where you are going To a
moſt feſtuant preparatiō we are bound to the like, Our
poſt ſhall be ſwift and intelligence betwixt vs, Farewell
deere ſiſter, farewell my Lord of Gloſter,
How now whers the King?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: My Lord of Gloſter hath conueyed him hence,
Some ﬁue or ſixe and thirtie of his Knights
hot queſtrits after him,met him at gate,
who with ſome other of the Lords dependants
are gone with him towards Douer, where they boaſt
to haue well armed friends.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Get horſes for your miſtris.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Farewell ſweet Lord and ſiſter.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Edmund farewell. goe ſeeke the traytor Gloſter.
Pinion him like a theefe, bring him before vs,
Though we may not paſſe vpon his life
Without the forme of Iuſtice, yet our power
Shall doe a curteſie to our wrath,which men
may blame But not controule,
whoſe there, the traytor?

scene.stagedir: Enter Gloſter brought in by two or three,

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Ingratfull Fox tis hee.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Bind faſt his corkie armes.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: What meanes your Graces,
good my friends conſider, You are my geſts,
doe me no foule play friends.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Bind him I ſay.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Hard hard; O ﬁlthie traytor!

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Vnmercifull Lady as you are, I am true.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: To this chaire bind him,
villaine thou ſhalt ﬁnd —

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: By the kind Gods tis moſt ignobly done,
to pluck me by the beard.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: So white and ſuch a Traytor.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Naughty Ladie,
theſe haires which thou doſt rauiſh from my chin
Will quicken and accuſe thee, I am your hoſt.
With robbers hands, my hoſpitable fauours
You ſhould not ruﬀell thus, what will you doe.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Come ſir,
what letters had you late from France?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Be ſimple anſwerer, for we know the truth.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: And what confederacy haue you with the tratours
late footed in the kingdome?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: To whoſe hands
you haue ſent the lunaticke King ſpeake?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I haue a letter geſſingly ſet downe
Which came from one that’s of a neutrall heart,
And not from one oppos’d.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Cunning.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: And falſe.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Where haſt thou ſent the King?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: To Douer.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Wherefore to Douer?
waſt thou not charg’d at perill —

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Wherefore to Douer? let him ﬁrſt anſwere that.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I am tied tot’h ſtake,
and I muſt ſtand the courſe.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Wherefore to Douer ſir?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Becauſe I would not ſee thy cruell nayles
Pluck out his poore old eyes, nor thy ﬁerce ſiſter
In his annoynted ﬂeſh raſh boriſh phangs,
The Sea with ſuch a ſtorme on his lowd head
In hell blacke night indur’d, would haue bod vp
And quencht the ſtelled ﬁres,
yet poore old heart, Hee holpt the heauens to rage,
If wolues had at thy gate heard that dearne time
Thou ſhouldſt haue ſaid,good Porter turne the key,
All cruels elſe ſubſcrib’d but I ſhall ſee
The winged vengeance ouertake ſuch children.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Seet ſhalt thou neuer, fellowes hold the chaire,
Vponthoſe eyes of thine, Ile ſet my foote.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: He that will thinke to liue till he be old
Giue me ſome helpe, O cruell, O ye Gods!

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: One ſide will mocke another, tother to.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: If you ſee vengeance---

speech.speaker: Seruant.
speech.line: Hold your hand my Lord
I haue ſeru’d euer ſince I was a child
But better ſeruice haue I neuer done you,
thē now to bid you hold.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: How now you dogge.

speech.speaker: Seru.
speech.line: If you did weare a beard vpon your chin
id’e ſhake it on this quarrell,what doe you meane?

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: My villaine.

speech.speaker: Seru.
speech.line: Why then come on, and take the chance of anger.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Giue me thy ſword, a peſant ſtand vp thus.

scene.stagedir: Shee takes a ſword and runs at him behind.

speech.speaker: Seruant.
speech.line: Oh I am ſlaine my Lord, yet haue you one eye left
to ſee ſome miſchiefe on him,oh!

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Leaſt it ſee more preuent it, out vild Ielly
Where is thy luſter now?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: All darke and comfortles,
wher’s my ſonne Edmund?
Edmund vnbridle all the ſparks of nature,
to quit this horrid a.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Out villaine,
thou calſt on him that hates thee, it was he
that made the ouerture of thy treaſons to vs,
who is too good to pittie thee.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: O my follies, then Edgar was abus’d,
Kind Gods forgiue me that,and proſper him.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Goe thruſt him out at gates, and let him ſmell
his way to Douer,
how iſt my Lord? how looke you?

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: I haue receiu’d a hurt, follow me Ladie,
Turne out that eyles villaine, throw this ſlaue
vpon The dungell Regan,I bleed apace,
vntimely Comes this hurt, giue me your arme.

speech.speaker: Seruant.
speech.line: Ile neuer care what wickednes I doe, If this man come to good.

speech.speaker: 2 Seruant.
speech.line: If ſhe liue long, & in the end meet the old courſe
of death, women will all turne monſters.

speech.speaker: 1 Ser.
speech.line: Lets follow the old Earle,and get the bedlom
To lead him where he would,his madnes
Allows it ſelfe to any thing.

speech.speaker: 2 Ser.
speech.line: Goe thou, ile fetch ſome flaxe and whites of egges to
apply to his bleeding fae,now heauen helpe him.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Yet better thus, and knowne to be contemnd,
Then ſtill contemn’d and ﬂattered to be worſt,
The loweſt and moſt deieed thing of Fortune
Stands ſtill in experience,liues not in feare,
The lamentable change is from the beſt,
The worſt returnes to laughter,
Who’s here,my father parti,eyd,world,world,O world!
But that thy ſtrange mutations made vs hate thee,
Life would not yeeld to age.
speech.stagedir: Enter Gloſt. led by an old man.

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: O my good Lord, I haue beene your tenant,
& your fathers tenant this foreſcore---

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Away, get thee away, good friend be gon,
Thy comforts can doe me no good at all,
Thee they may hurt.

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: Alack ſir, you cannot ſee your way.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I haue no way, and therefore want no eyes,
I ſtumbled when I ſaw, full oft tis ſeene
Our meanes ſecure vs,and our meare defes
Proue our comodities,ah deere ſonne Edgar,
The food of thy abuſed fathers wrath,
Might I but liue to ſee thee in my tuch,
Id’e ſay I had eyes againe.

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: How now whoſe there?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: O Gods, who iſt can ſay I am at the worſt,
I am worſe then ere I was.

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: Tis poore mad Tom.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: And worſe I may be yet, the worſt is not.
As long as we can ſay, this is the worſt.

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: Fellow where goeſt?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Is it a begger man?

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: Mad man,and begger to.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: A has ſome reaſon, elſe he could not beg,
In the laſt nights ſtorme I ſuch a fellow ſaw,
Which made me thinke a man a worme,my ſonne
Came then into my mind,and yet my mind
Was then ſcarce friendes with him,
I haue heard more ſince,
As flies toth’ wanton boyes,are we toth’ Gods,
They bitt vs for their ſport.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: How ſhould this be,
bad is the trade that muſt play the foole to ſorrow
angring it ſelfe and others, bleſſe thee maiſter.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Is that the naked fellow?

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: I my Lord.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Then prethee get thee gon,if for my ſake
Thou wilt oretake vs here a mile or twaine
Ith’way toward Douer, doe it for ancient loue
And bring ſome couering for this naked ſoule
Who Ile intreate to leade me.

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: Alack ſir he is mad.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Tis the times plague,
when madmen lead the blind,
Doe as I bid thee, or rather doe thy pleaſure,
Aboue the reſt, be gon.

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: Ile bring him the beſt parrell that I haue
Come on’t what will.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Sirrah naked fellow.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Poore Toms a cold, I cannot dance it farther.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Come hither fellow.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Bleſſe thy ſweete eyes, they bleed.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Knowſt thou the way to Douer?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Both ſtile and gate, horſe way, and foot-path,
Poore Tom hath been ſcard out of his good wits, Bleſſe
the good man from the foule ﬁend,
Of luſt,as Obedient, Hobbiididince Prince of dumbnes,
Maliu of Healing,Mode of murder, Stiberdigabit of
Mobing,& Mobing who ſince poſſeſſes chambermaids
And waiting women,ſo, bleſſe thee maiſter.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Here take this purſe, thou whom the heauens plagues
Haue humbled to all ſtrokes, that I am wretched,
makes thee The happier, heauens deale ſo ſtill,
Let the ſuperﬂuous and luſt-dieted man
That ſtands your ordinance, that will not ſee
Becauſe he does not feele,feele your power quickly,
So diſtribution ſhould vnder exceſſe,
And each man haue enough, doſt thou know Douer?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I maſter.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: There is a cliﬀe whoſe high & bending head
Lookes ﬁrmely in the conﬁned deepe,
Bring me but to the very brimme of it
And ile repaire the miſery thou doſt beare
With ſomething rich about me, From that place
I ſhal no leading need.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Giue me thy arme,
poore Tom ſhall lead thee.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Welcome my Lord, I maruaile our mild huſband
Not met vs on the way,now wher’s your maiſter?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Madam within,but neuer man ſo chang’d,
I told him of the army that was landed,
he ſmild at it, I told him you were coming,
his anſwere was the worſe, of Gloſters treacherie,
and of the loyall ſeruice of his ſonne
when I enform’d him, then he cald me ſott,
and told me I had turnd the wrong ſide out,
what hee ſhould moſt deſire ſeemes pleaſant to him,
what like oﬀenſiue.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Then ſhall you goe no further
It is the cowiſh terrer of his ſpirit
That dares not vndertake, hele not feele wrongs
Which tie him to an anſwere, our wiſhes on the way
May proue eﬀes, backe Edgar to my brother,
Haſten his muſters, and condu his powers
I muſt change armes at home,and giue the diſtaﬀe
Into my husbands hands, this truſty ſeruant
Shall paſſe betweene vs, ere long you are like to heare
If you dare venture in your owne behalfe
A miſtreſſes command, weare this, ſpare ſpeech,
Decline your head: this kiſſe if it durſt ſpeake
Would ſtretch thy ſpirits vp into the ayre,
Conceaue and far you well.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Yours in the ranks of death.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: My moſt deer Gloſter,
to thee a womans ſeruices are dew
A foole vſurps my bed.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Madam, here comes my Lord.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: I haue beene worth the whiſtling.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Oh Gonoril,
you are not worth the duſt which the rude wind
Blowes in your face,I feare your diſpoſition
That nature which contemnes ith origin
Cannot be bordered certaine in it ſelfe,
She that her ſelfe will ſliuer and disbranch
From her materiall ſap, perforce muſt wither,
And comne to deadly vſe.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: No more, the text is fooliſh.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Wiſedome and goodnes,to the vild ſeeme vild,
Filths fauor but themſelues,what haue you done?
Tigers, not daughters, what haue you perform’d?
A father,and a gracious aged man
Whoſe reuerence euen the head-lugd beare would lick.
Moſt barbarous, moſt degenerate haue you madded.
Could my good brother ſuﬀer you to doe it?
A man,a Prince, by him ſo benifited,
If that the heauens doe not their viſible ſpirits
Send quickly downe to tame this vild oﬀences,it will come
Humanity muſt perforce pray on it felt like monſters of the deepe.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Milke liuerd man
That beareſt a cheeke for bloes, a head for wrongs,
Who haſt not in thy browes an eye deſeruing
thine honour, From thy ſuﬀering,
that not know’ſt,foolsdo thoſe vilains pitty
Who are puniſht ere they haue done their miſchiefe,
Wher’s thy drum? France ſpreds his banners in out noyſeles land,
With plumed helme,thy ſtate begins thereat
Whil’ſt thou a morall foole ſits ſtill and cries
Alack why does he ſo?

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: See thy ſelfe deuill,
proper deformity ſhewes not in the ﬁend,
ſo horrid as in woman.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Oh vaine foole!

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Thou changed, and ſelfe-couerd thing for ſhame
Be-monſter not thy feature,wer’t my fitnes
To let theſe hands obay my bloud,
They are apt enough to diſtecate and teare
Thy fleſh and bones, how ere thou art a ﬁend,
A womans ſhape doth ſhield thee.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Marry your manhood mew —

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: What newes.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: O my good Lord the Duke of Cornwals dead,
ſlaine by his ſeruant,going to put out
the other eye of Gloſter.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Gloſters eyes?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: A ſeruant that he bred,thrald with remorſe,
Oppos’d againſt the a, bending his ſword
To his great maiſter,who thereat inraged
Flew on him, and amongſt them, feld him dead,
But not without that harmefull ſtroke, which ſince
Hath pluckt him after.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: This ſhewes you are aboue
you Iuſtiſers, That theſe our nether crimes
ſo ſpeedely can venge. But O poore Gloſter
loſt he his other eye.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Both, both my Lord,
this letter Madam craues a ſpeedy anſwer.
Tis from your ſiſter.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: One way I like this well,
But being widow and my Gloſter with her,
May all the building on my fancie plucke,
Vpon my hatefull life,another way
the newes is not ſo tooke, Ile reade and anſwer.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Where was his ſonne
when they did take his eyes.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Come with my Lady hither.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: He is not here.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: No my good Lord I met him backe againe.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Knowes he the wickedneſſe.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: I my good Lord twas he informd againſt him,
And quit the houſe on purpoſe that there puniſhment
Might haue the freer courſe.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Gloſter I liue
to thanke thee for the loue thou ſhewedſt the King,
And to reuenge thy eyes, come hither friend,
Tell me what more thou knoweſt.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Why the Kind of Fraunce is ſo ſuddenly gone backe,
know you no reaſon.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Something he left imperfe in the ſtate,which ſince his comming forth is thought of,
which imports to he Kingdome, So much feare and danger that his perſonall returne was moſt
required and neceſſarie.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Who hath he left behind him, General.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: The Marſhall of France Monſier la Făr.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Did your letters pierce the queene to any demonſtratiō of griefe,

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: I ſay ſhe tooke them, read them in my preſence,
And now and then an ample teare trild downe
Her delicate cheeke,it ſeemed ſhe was a queene ouer her paſſion,
Who moſt rebell-like,fought to be King ore her.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: O then it moued her.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Not to a rage,patience and ſorow ſtreme,
Who ſhould expreſſe her goodlieſt you haue ſeene,
Sun ſine and raine at once, her ſmiles and teares,
Were like a better way thoſe happie ſmiles,
That playd on her ripe lip ſeeme not to know!
What gueſts were in her eyes which parted thence,
As pearles from diamonds dropt in briefe,
Sorow would be a raritie moſt beloued,
If all could ſo become it.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Made ſhe no verball queſtion.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Faith once or twice ſhe heau’d the name of father,
Pantinglyforth as if it preſt her heart,
Cried ſiſters,ſiſters, ſhame of Ladies ſiſters:
Kent, father, ſiſters, what ith ſorme ith night,
Let pitie not be beloeſt there ſhe ſhooke,
The holy water from her heauenly eyes,
And clamour moyſtened her, then away ſhe ſtarted,
To deale with griefe alone.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: It is the ſtars,the ſtars aboue vs gouerne our conditions,
Elſe one ſelfe mate and make could not beget,
Such diﬀerent iſſues, you ſpoke not with her ſince.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Was this before the King returnd.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: No,ſince.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Well ſir, the poore diſtreſſed Lear’s ith towne,
Who ſome time in his better tune remembers,
What we are come about,and by no meanes will yeeld to ſee his daughter.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Why good ſir?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: A ſoveraigne ſhame ſo elbows him his own vnkindnes
That ſtript her from his benediion turnd her,
To ſorraine caſualties gave her deare rights.
To his dog-harted daughters, theſe things ſting his mind,
So venomoufly that burning ſhame detaines him from Cordelia.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Alack poore Gentleman.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Ol Albanies andCornewals powers you heard not.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Tis ſo they are a foote.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Well ſir, ile bring you to our maiſter Lear,
And leaue you to attend him ſome deere cauſe,
Will in concealement wrap me vp awhile,
When I am knowne aright you ſhall not greene,
Lending me this acquaintance, I pray you go along with me.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Alack tis he, why he was met euen now,
As mad as the vent ſea ſinging aloud,
Crownd with ranke femiter and furrow weedes,
With hor-docks,hemlocke,netles,cookow ﬂowers,
Darnell and all the idle weedes that grow,
In our ſuſtayning, corne, a centurie is ſent forth,
Search euery acre in the hie growne ﬁeld,
And bring him to our eye, what can mans wiſdome
In the reſtoring his bereued ſence,he that can helpe him
Take all my outward worth*

speech.speaker: Do.
speech.line: There is meanes Madame.
Our foſter nurſe of nature is repoſe,
The which he lackes that to prouoke in him,
Are many ſimples operatiue whoſe power,
Will cloſe the eye of anguiſh.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: All bleſt ſecrets
all you vnpubliſht vertues of the earth,
Spring with my teares beaydant and remediat,
In the good mans diſtreſſe,ſeeke,ſeeke,for him,
Leſt his vngouernd rage diſſolue the life.
That wants the meanes to lead it.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: News Madam,
the Brittiſh powers are marching hitherward.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Tis knowne before, our preparation ſtands
In expe ation of them,ó deere father
It is thy buſines that I go about, therfore great France
My mourning and important teares hath pitied,
No blowne ambition doth our armes in fight
But loue, deere loue,and ourag’d fathers right,
Soone may I heare and ſee him.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: But are my brothers powers ſet forth?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I Madam.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Himſelfe in perſon?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Madam with much ado,
your ſiſter as the better ſoldier.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Lord Edmund ſpake not with your Lady at home.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: No Madam.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: What might import my ſiſters letters to him?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I know not Lady.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Faith he is poſted hence on ſerious matter,
It was great ignorance, Gloſters eyes being out
To let him liue, where he ariues he moues
All harts againſt vs.and now I thinke is gone
In pitie of his miſery to diſpatch
his nighted life, Moreouer to diſcrie
the ſtrength at’h army.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I muſt needs after him with my letters

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Our troope ſets forth to morrow ſtay with vs,
The wayes are dangerous.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I may not Madame
my Lady charg’d my dutie in this buſines.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Why ſhould ſhe write to Edmund?
might not you Tranſport her purpoſes by word, belike
Some thing, I know not what,ile loue thee much,
Let me vnſeale the letter.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Madam, I’d e rather —

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I know your Lady does not loue her huſband
I am ſure of that, and at her late being here
Shee gaue ſtrange aliads,and moſt ſpeaking lookes
To noble Edmund, I know you are of her boſome.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I Madam.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I ſpeake in vnderſtanding,for I know’t,
Therefore I doe aduiſe you take this note,
My Lord is dead, Edmund and I haue talkt,
And more conuenient is he for my hand
Then for your Ladies, you may gather more
If you doe ﬁnd him,pray you giue him this,
And when your miſtris heares thus much from you
I pray deſire her call her wiſedome to her,
ſo farewell,
If you doe chance to heare of that blind traytor,
Preferment fals on him that cuts him oﬀ.

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: Would I could meet Madam, I would ſhew
What Lady I doe follow.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Fare thee well.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: When ſhall we come toth’ top of that ſame hill?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: You do climbe it vpnow,looke how we labour?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Me thinks the ground is euen.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Horrible ſteepe,
harke doe you heare the ſea?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: No truly.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Why then your other fenſes grow imperfe
By your eyes anguiſh.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: So may it be indeed.
Me thinkes thy voyce is altered, and thou ſpeakeſt
With better phraſe and matter then thou didſt.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Y’ar much deceaued, in nothing am I chang’d
But in my garments.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Me thinkes y’ar better ſpoken.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Come on
ſir,
her’s the place, ſtand ſtill, how feareful
And dizi tis to caſt ones eyes ſo low
The crowes and choghes that wing the midway ayre
Shew ſcarce ſo groſſe as beetles halfe way downe
Hangs one that gathers ſampire,dreadfull trade,
Me thinkes he ſeemes no bigger then his head,
The fiſhermen that walke vpon the beach
Appeare like miſe,and yon tall anchoring barke
Diminiſht to her cock, her cock a boui
Almoſt too ſmall for ſight, the murmuring ſurge
That on the vnnumbred idle peeble chaﬀes
Cannot be heard, its ſo hie ile looke no more,
Leaſt my braine turne,and the deﬁcient ſight
Topple downe headlong.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Set me where you ſtand?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Giue me your hand,
you are now within a foot Of th’extreme verge,
for all beneath the Moone Would I not leape vpright.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Let goe my hand,
Here friend’s another purſſe, in it a iewell,
Well worth a poore mans taking, Fairies and Gods
Proſper it with thee, got thou farther oﬀ,
Bid me farewell,and let me heare thee going.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Now fare you well good ſir.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: VVith all my heart.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Why I do trifell thus with his diſpaire
is done to cure it.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: O you mightie Gods,
This world I doe renounce and in your ſights
Shake patiently my great aﬀliion oﬀ,
If I could beare it longer and not fall
To quarel with your great oppoſles wils
My ſnurﬀ and loathed part of nature ſhould
Burne it ſelfe out, if Edgar liue, O bleſſe,
Now fellow fare thee well.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Gon ſir,farewell,
and yet I know not how conceit my robbe
the treaſurie of life, when life it ſelfe
yealds to the theft, had he beene where he thought
by this had thought beene paſt, aliue or dead,
ho you ſir, heare you ſir, ſpeake,
thus might he paſſe indeed, yet he reuiues,
what are you ſir?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Away and let me die.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Hadſt thou beene ought
but goſmore feathers ayre,
So many fadome downe precipitating
Thou hadſt ſhiuerd like an egge, but thou doſt breath
Haſt heauy ſubſtance,bleedſt not,ſpeakeſt,art ſound,
Ten maſts at each,make not the altitude,
VVhich thou haſt perpendicularly fell,
Thy lifes a miracle,ſpeake yet againe.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: But haue I fallen or no!

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: From the dread ſommons of this chalkie borne,
Looke vp a hight, the ſhrill gorg’d larke ſo farre
Cannot bee ſeene or heard, doe but looke vp?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Alack I haue no eyes
Is wretchednes depriu’d that beneﬁt
To end it ſelfe by death twas yet ſome comfort
When miſery could beguile the tyrants rage
And fruſtrate his proud will.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Giue me your arme?
Vp,ſo,how feele you your legges,you ſtand.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Too well, too well.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: This is aboue all ſtrangenes,
Vpon the crowne of the cliﬀe what thing was that
Which parted from you.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: A poore vnfortunate bagger.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: As I ſtood here below me thoughts his eyes
VVere two full Moones,a had a thouſand noſes
Hornes,welk’t and waued like the enridged ſea,
It was ſome ﬁend, therefore thou happy father
Thinke that the cleereſt Gods, who made them honours
Of mens impoſſibilities, haue preſerued thee.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I doe remember now,henceforth ile beare
Aﬀliion till it doe crie out it ſelfe
Enough, enough and die that thing you ſpeake of,
I tooke it for a man, often would it ſay
The ﬁend the ﬁend,he led me to that place

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Bare free & patient thoughts,
but who comes here
The ſafer ſence will neare accōmodate
his maiſter thus.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No they cannot touch mee for coyning,I am the
king himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: O thou ſide pearcing ſight.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Nature is aboue Art in that reſpe, ther’s your
preſſe money,that fellow handles his bow like a crow-
keeper,draw me a clothiers yard, looke,looke a
mowſe,peace,peace, this toſted cheeſe will
do it ther’s my gauntlet,ile proue it on a gyant,
bring vp the browne-billes,O well ﬂowne bird in the ayre,
hagh,giue the word?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Sweet Margerum.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Paſſe.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I know that voyce.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ha Gonorill, ha Regan, they ﬂattered
mee like a dogge, and tould me I had the white haires in
my beard, ere the black ones were there, to ſay I and
no,to euery thing I ſaide, I and no toe, was no good
diuinitie, when the raine came to wet me once, and the
winde to make mee chatter, when the thunder would not
peace at my bidding,there I found them there I ſmelt them
out, goe toe, they are not men of their words, they told
mee I was euery thing,tis a lye, I am not argue-proofe.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: The tricke of that voyce I doe well remember,
ift not the King?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I euer inch a King
when I do ſtare,ſee how the ſubie quakes,
I pardon that mans life, what was thy cauſe,
adultery? thou ſhalt not die for adulterie,
no the wren goes toot, and the ſmal guilded ﬂie
doe letcher in my ſight, let copulation thriue,
for Gloſters baſtard ſon was kinder to his father
then my daughters got tweene the lawfull ſheets,
toot luxurie,pell, mell, for I lacke ſouldiers,
behold yon ſimpring dame whoſe face between her
forkes preſageth ſnow, that minces vertue, and do ſhake
the head heare of pleaſures name to ﬁtchew nor
the ſoyled horſe goes toot with a more riotous appetite,
down frō the waſt tha’re centaures, though
women all aboue, but to the girdle doe the gods inherit,
beneath is all the ﬁends,thers hell, thers darknſſe,
ther’s the ſulphury pit, burning, ſcalding, ſtench,
conſumation,ﬁe,ﬁe,ﬁe,pah,pah, Giue mee an ounce
of Ciuet, good Apothecarie, to ſweeten my imagination,
ther’s money for thee.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: O let me kiſſe that hand.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Here wipe it ﬁrſt,
it ſmels of mortalitie.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: O ruind peece of nature, this great world
ſhould ſo weare out to naught,
do you know me?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I remember thy eyes well inough, doſt thou
ſquiny on me, no do thy worſt blind Cupid, ile not
loue, reade thou that challenge, marke but the penning
oft.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Were all the letters ſunnes I could not ſee one.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I would not take this from report,
it is, and my heart breakes at it.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Read.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: What I with the caſe of eyes

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Oh ho,are you there with me, no eyes in your
head, not no mony in your purſe, your eyes are in a heauie
caſe,your purſe in a light, yet you ſee how this world
goes.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I ſee it feelingly.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What art mad, a man may ſee how the world
goes with no eyes, looke with thy cares, ſee how
yon Iuſtice railes vpon yon ſimple theefe, harke in
thy eare handy, dandy, which is
the theefe, which is the Iuſtice,thou haſt ſeene a farmers
dogge barke at a begger.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I ſir.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: And the creature runne from the cur,there thou
mightſt behold the great image of authoritie, a dogge,
ſo bade in oﬃce, thou raſcall beadle hold thy bloudy
hand, why doſt thou laſh that whore, ſtrip thine owne
backe,thy bloud hotly luſts to vſe her in that kind for which
thou whipſt her, the vſurer hangs the coſioner, through
tottered raggs,ſmal vices do appeare,robes
& furd-gownes hides all, get thee glaſſe eyes, and like a ſcuruy
politician ſeeme to ſee the
things thou doeſt not, no now pull oﬀ my
bootes,harder, harder, ſo.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: O matter and impertinencie mixt
reaſon in madneſſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: If thou wilt weepe my fortunes take my eyes,
I knowe thee well inough thy name is Gloſter,
thou muſt be patient, we came crying hither,
thou knoweſt the ﬁrſt time that we ſmell the aire,
we wayle and cry I will preach to thee marke mee.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Alack alack the day.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: VVhen we are borne, we crie that wee are come
to this great ſtage of fooles, this a good blocke.
It were a delicate ſtratagem to ſhoot
a troupe of horſe with fell,& when I
haue ſtole vpon theſe ſonne in lawes,
then kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: O here he is, lay hands vpon him ſirs,
your moſt deere

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No reskue,what a priſoner,I am eene
the naturall foole of Fortune, vſe me well
you ſhall haue ranſome, let mee haue a churgion
I am cut to the braines.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: You ſhall haue any thing.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No ſeconds, all my ſelfe,
why this would make a man of ſalt
to vſe his eyes for garden waterpots,I and laying Autums duſt.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I will die bravely like a bridegroome,what? I will be Iouiall,
come, come, I am a King my maiſters, know you that.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: You are a royall one, and we obey you.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Then theres life int,nay and you get it you
ſhall get it with running.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: A ſight moſt pitifull in the meaneſt wretch,
paſt ſpeaking of in a king:thou haſt one daughter
who redeemes nature from the generall curſe
which twaine hath brought her to.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Haile gentle ſir.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: ſir ſpeed you, whats your will.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Do you heare ought of a battell toward.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Moſt ſure and vulgar
euery one here’s that That can diſtinguiſh ſence.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: But by your fauour
how neers the other army.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Neere and on ſpeed fort the maine deſcryes,
Standſt on the howerly thoughts.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I thanke you ſir thats all.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Though that the Queene on ſpeciall cauſe is here,
Hir army is moued on.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I thanke you ſir.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: You euer gentle gods take my breath from me,
Let not my worſer spirit tempt me againe,
To dye before you pleaſe.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Well, pray you father.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Now good ſir what are you.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: A moſt poore man made lame by Fortunes blowes,
Who by the Art of knowne and feeling ſorrowes,
Am pregnant to good pitty,giue me your hand
Ile leade you to ſome biding.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Hartie thankes,
the bounty and the benizon of heauen,
to boot, to boot.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: A proclaimed prize, moſt happy,
that eyles head of thine was ﬁrſt framed ﬂeſh
to rayſe my fortunes, thou moſt vnhappy traytor,
briefly thy ſelfe remember, the ſword is out
that muſt deſtroy thee.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Now let thy friendly hand
put ſtrength enough to’t.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: VVherefore bould peſant
durſt thou ſupport a publiſht traytor, hence
leaſt the infeion of his fortune take
like hold on thee, let go his arme?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Chill not let goe ſir
without cagion.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Let goe ſlaue, or thou dieſt.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Good Gentleman goe your gate, let poore
voke paſſe, and chud haue beene ſwaggar’d out of my life,
it would not haue beene ſo long by a vortnight, nay
come not neare the old man, keepe out cheuore ye, or ile
trie whether your coſterd or my bat be the harder,
ile be plaine with you.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Out dunghill.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Chill picke your teeth ſir,come,no matter for
your foyns.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Slaue thou haſt ſlaine me, villaine take my purſſe,
If euer thou wilt thriue, burie my bodie,
And giue the letters which thou ﬁnd’ſt about me
To Edmund Earle of Gloer, ſeeke him out,
vpon The Brittiſh partie, ô vntimely death! death.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I know thee well, ſeruiceable villaine,
As dutious to the vices of thy miſtris,
as badnes would deſire.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: What is he dead?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Sit you downe father. reſt you,
lets ſee his pockets Theſe letters that he ſpeakes of,
may be my friends, Hee’s dead, I am only ſorrow
he had no other deathſmâ Let vs ſee
leaue gentle waxe and manners blame vs not
To know our enemies minds, weed rip their hearts.
Their papers is more lawfull.

line.recite: Let our reciprocall vowes be remembred. you haue many
opportunities to cut him oﬀ if your will want not, time and
place will be fruitfully oﬀered, there is nothing done, If he
returne the conquerom, then am I the priſoner, and his bed my
iayle, from the lothed warmth whereof deliuer me,and ſupply
your wife (ſo I would ſay) your aﬀeionate
ſeruant and for you her owne for Venter, Gonorill.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Oh Indiſtinguiſht ſpace of womans wit,
A plot vpon her vertuous husbands life.
And the exchange my brother heere in the ſands,
Thee ile rake vp, the poſt vnſaniﬁed
Of murtherous leachers, and in the mature time,
With this vngratious paper ſtrike the ſight
Of the death praiſ’d Duke, for him tis well,
That of thy death and buſineſſe I can tell.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: The King is mad,
how ſtiﬀe is my vild ſence,
That I ſtand vp and haue ingenious feeling
Of my huge ſorowes, better I were diſtra,
So ſhould my thoughts be ſenced from my griefes,
And woes by wrong imaginations looſe
The knowledge of themſelues.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Giue me your hand
far oﬀ me thinks I heare the beaten drum,
Come father ile beſtow you with a friend.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: O thou good Kent
how ſhall I liue and worke
to match thy goodnes,
My life will be too ſhort
and euery meaſure faile me.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: To be acknowledgd madame is ore payd,
All my reports go with the modeſt truth,
Nor more, nor clipt, but ſo.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Be better ſuited
theſe weeds are memories of thoſe Worſer howers,
I prithe put them oﬀ.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Pardon me deere madame,
Yet to be knowne ſhortens my made intent,
My boone I make it that you know me not,
Till time and I thinke meete.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Then beet ſo, my good Lord
how does the king.

speech.speaker: Do.
speech.line: Madame ſleepes ſtill.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: O you kind Gods
cure this great breach in his abuſed nature,
The vntund and hurrying ſences,O wind vp
Of this child changed father.

speech.speaker: Do.
speech.line: So pleaſe your Maieſtie
that we may wake the king. He hath ſlept long.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Be gouernd by your knowledge and proceed,
Ith ſway of your owne will is he arayd,

speech.speaker: Do.
speech.line: I madam, in the heauineſſe of ſleepe,
We put freſh garments on him,

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Good madam be by, when we do awake him
I doubt not of his temperance.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Very Well.

speech.speaker: Do.
speech.line: Pleaſe you draw neere,louder the muſicke there,

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: O my deer father reſtoratiō hang
thy medicin on my lips, And let this kis
repaire thoſe violent harmes that my two ſiſters
Haue in thy reuerence made.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Kind and deere Princeſſe,

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Had you not bene their father theſe white ﬂakes,
Had challengd pitie of them,was this a face
To be exposſd againſt the warring winds,
To ſtand againſt the deepe dread bolted thunder,
In the moſt terrible and nimble ſtroke
Of quick croſſe lightning to watch poore Por du,
With this thin helme mine iniurious dogge,
Though he had bit me,
ſhould haue ſtood that night Againſt my ﬁre,
and waſt thou faine poore father,
To houill thee with ſwine and rogues forlorne,
In ſhort and muſtie ſtraw,alack,alack,
Tis wonder that thy life and wits at once
Had not concluded all, he wakes ſpeake to him.

speech.speaker: Do.
speech.line: Madam do you, tis ﬁtteſt.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: How does my royall Lord,
how fares your maieſtie.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: You do me wrong to take me out ath graue,
Thou art a ſoule in bliſſe, but I am bound
Vpon a wheele of ﬁre, that mine owne teares
Do ſcald like molten lead.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Sir know me.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Yar a ſpirit I know, where did you dye.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Still,ſtill,farre wide.

speech.speaker: Do.
speech.line: Hees ſcarce awake,
let him alone a while.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Where haue I bene,
where am I faire day light,
I am mightily abuſd, I ſhould ene dye with pitie,
To ſee another thus, I know not what to ſay,
I will not ſweare theſe are my hands, lets ſee,
I feele this pin pricke, would I were aſſur’d
of my condition.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: O looke vpon me ſir,
and hold your hands in benediion or’e me,
no ſir you muſt not kneele.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Pray doe not mocke,
I am a very fooliſh fond old man,
Foureſcore and vpward,and to deale plainly
I feare I am not in my perfe mind,
Mee thinks I ſhould know you, and know this man;
Yet I am doubtfull, for I am mainly ignorant
What place this is, and all the skill I haue
Remembers not theſe garments, nor I know not
Where I did lodge laſt night,doe not laugh at me,
For as I am a man, I thinke this Ladie
To be my child Cordelia.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: And ſo I am.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Be your teares wet,
yes faith, I pray weep not,
If you haue poyſen for mee I will drinke it,
I know you doe not loue me, for your ſiſters
Haue as I doe remember, done me wrong,
You haue ſome cauſe, they haue not.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: No cauſe,no cauſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Am I in France?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: In your owne kingdome ſir.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Doe not abuſe me?

speech.speaker: Do.
speech.line: Be comforted good Madame, the great rage
you ſee is cured in him, and yet it is danger to make him
euen ore the time hee has loſt, deſire him to goe in,
trouble him no more till further ſetling?

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Wilt pleaſe your highnes walke?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: You muſt beare with me,
pray now forget and forgiue,
I am old and fooliſh.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Holds it true ſir that the Duke of Cornwall was ſo ſlaine?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Moſt certaine ſir.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Who is conduor of his people?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: As tis ſaid,the baſtard ſonne of Gloer.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: They ſay Edgar his baniſht ſonne is with the Earle of
Kent in Germanie.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Report is changeable,tis time to looke about,
The powers of the kingdome approach apace.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: The arbiterment is like to be bloudie,fare you well ſir.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: My poynt and period will be throughly wrought,
Or well, or ill,as this day es barr els fought.

scene.stagedir: Enter Edmund, Regan, and their powers.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Know of the Duke if his laſt purpoſe hold,
Or whether ſince he is aduis’d by ought
To change the courſe, hee’s full of alteration
And ſelfe reprouing, bring his conſtant pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Our ſiſters man is certainly miſcaried,

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Tis to be doubted Madam,

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Now ſweet Lord,
You know the goodnes I intend vpon you,
Tell me but truly, but then ſpeak the truth,
Doe you not loue my ſiſter?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I, honor’d loue.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: But haue you neuer found my brothers way,
To the forfended place?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: That thought abuſes you.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I am doubtfull that you haue beene coniun and boſom’d
with hir,as far as we call hirs.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: No by mine honour Madam.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I neuer ſhall indure hir, deere my Lord
bee not familiar with her.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Feare me not, ſhee and the Duke her husband.

speech.stagedir: Enter Albany and Gonerill with troupes.

speech.speaker: Gono.
speech.line: I had rather looſe the battaile, then that ſiŵter ſhould
looſen him and mee.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Our very louing ſiſter well be-met
For this I heare the King is come to his daughter
With others, whome the rigour of our ſtate
Forſt to crie out, where I could not be honeſt
I neuer yet was valiant, for this buſines
It touches vs, as France invades our land
Not bolds the King, with others whome I feare,
Moſt iuſt and heavy cauſes made oppoſe.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Sir you ſpeake nobly.

speech.speaker: Regan.
speech.line: Why is this reaſon’d?

speech.speaker: Gono.
speech.line: Combine togither gainſt the enemy,
For theſe domeſtique dore particulars
Are not the queſtion here.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Let vs then determine with the auntient of warre
on our proceedings.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I ſhall attend you preſently at you tent.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Siſter you’l goe with vs?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Tis moſt conuenient, pray you goe with vs.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: O ho, I know the riddle, I will goe.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: If ere your Grace had ſpeech with man ſo poore,
Heare me one word.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Ile ouertake you, ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Before you fight the batrell ope this letter,
If you haue viory let the trumpet ſound
For him that brought it, wretched though I ſeeme,
I can produce a champion that will proue
What is auowched there, if you miſcary,
Your buſines of the world hath ſo an end,
Fortune loues you.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Stay till I haue read the letter.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I was forbid it,
when time ſhall ſerue let but the Herald cry
and ile appeare againe.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Why farethee well, I will ore-looke the paper.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: The enemies in view, draw vp your powers
Hard is the queſſe of their great ſtrength and forces
By dilligent diſcouery, but your haſt
is now vrg’d on you.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Wee will greet the time.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: To both theſe ſiſter haue I ſworne my loue,
Each iealous of the other as the ſting
are of the Adder, Which of them ſhall I take,
both one or neither, neither can bee inioy’d
If both remaine aliue, to take the widdow
Exaſperates,makes mad her ſiſter Gonorill,
And hardly ſhall I cary out my ſide
Her husband being aliue,now then we’le vſe
His countenadee for the battaile, which being done
Let her that would be rid of him deuiſe
His ſpeedie taking oﬀ, as for his mercy
Which he entends to Lear and to Cordelia:
The battaile done,and they within our power
Shall neuer ſee his pardon, for my ſtate
Stands on me to defend, not to debate,

scene.stagedir: Alarum. Enter the powers of France ouer the ſtage, Cordelia with her father is her hand.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Here father, take the ſhaddow of this buſh
For your good hoaſt, pray that the right may thriue
If euer I returne to you againe
ile bring you comfort.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Grace go with you ſir.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Away old man,giue me thy hand,away,
King Lear hath loſt,he and his daughter taine,
Giue me thy hand,come on.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: No farther ſir, a man may rot euen here.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: What in ill thoughts againe
men muſt indure,
Their going hence,euen as their coming hither,
Ripenes is all come on.

scene.stagedir: Enter Edmund, with Lear and Cordelia as priſoners.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Some oﬃcers take them away, good guard
Vntill their greater pleaſures beſt be knowne
That are to cenſure them.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: We are not the ﬁrſt
who with beſt meaning haue incurd The worſt,
for thee oppreſſed King am I caſt downe,
My ſelfe could elſe outfrowne falſe Fortunes frowne,
Shall we not ſee theſe daughters, and theſe ſiſters?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No,no,come lets away to priſon,
We two alone will ſing like birds it’h cage,
When thou doſt aske me bleſſing,ile kneele downe
And aske of thee forgiuenes, ſo weele liue
And pray,and ſing and tell old tales and laugh
At guilded butterﬂies, and heare poore rogues
Talke of Court newes, and weele talke with them to,
Who looſes, and who wins, whoſe in,whoſe out,
And take vpon’s the miſtery of things
As if we were Gods ſpies, and weele weare out
In a wal’d priſon,packs and ſes of great ones
That ebbe and ﬂow bith’ Moone.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Take them away.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Vpon ſuch ſacriﬁces my Cordelia,
The Gods thēſelues throw incenſe,
haue I caught thee?
He that parts vs ſhall bring a brand from heauen,
And ﬁre vs hence like Foxes, wipe thine eyes,
The good ſhall deuoure em, ﬂeach and fell,
Ere they ſhall make vs weepe?
wele ſee vm ſtarue ﬁrſt, come.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Come hither Captaine, harke.
Take thou this note,goe follow them to priſon,
One ſtep, I haue aduanct thee, thou doſt
As this inſtrus thee, thou doſt make thy way
To noble fortunes, know thou this that men
Are as the time is, to be tender minded
Does not become a ſword, thy great imployment
Will not beare queſtion, either ſay thout do’t,
Or thriue by other meanes.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Ile do’t my Lord.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: About it, and write happy when thou haſt don.
MarkeI ſay inſtantly, and carie it ſo
As I haue ſet it downe.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: I cannot draw a cart,nor eate dride oats,
If it bee mans worke ile do’t.

scene.stagedir: Enter Duke, the two Ladies, and others.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Sir, you haue ſhewed to day your valiant ſtrain,
And Fortune led you well,you haue the captiues
That were the oppoſites of this dayes ſtrife,
We doe require then of you, ſo to vſe them,
As we ſhall ﬁnd their merits, and our ſafty
May equally determine.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Sir I thought it ﬁt,
To ſend the old and miſerable King to ſome retention, and appointed guard,
Whoſe age had charmes in it,whoſe title more,
To pluck the common boſſome on his ſide,
And turne our impreſt launces in our eyes
Which doe commaund them, with him I ſent the queen
My reaſon,all the ſame and they are readie
to morrow, Or at further ſpace, to appeare
where you ſhall hold
Your ſeſſion at this time, wee ſeat and bleed,
The friend hath loſt his friend and the beſt quarrels
In the heat are curſt, by thoſe that feele their ſharp nes,
The queſtion of Cordelia and her father
Requires a ﬀtter place.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Sir by your patience,
I hold you but a ſubie of this warre,
not as a brother.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: That’s as we liſt to grace him,
Me thinkes our pleaſure ſhould haue beene demanded
Ere you had ſpoke ſo farre,he led our powers,
Bore the commiſſion of my place and perſon,
The which imediate may well ſtand vp,
And call it ſelfe your brother.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Not ſo hot,
in his owne grace hee doth exalt himſelfe
more then in your advancement.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: In my right
by me inueſted he com-peers the beſt.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: That were the moſt, if hee ſhould husband you.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Ieſters doe oft proue Prophets.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Hola, hola,
that eye that told you ſo, lookt but a ſquint.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Lady I am not well, els I ſhould anſwere
From a full ﬂowing ſtomack, Generall
Take thou my ſouldiers,priſoners,patrimonie,
Witnes the world that I create thee here
My Lord and maiſter.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Meane you to inioy him then?

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: The let alone lies not in your good will.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Nor in thine Lord.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Halfe blouded fellow, yes.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Let the drum ſtrike, and proue my title good.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Stay yet, heare reaſon, Edmund I arreſt thee
On capitall treaſon,and in thine attaint,
This gilded Serpent, for your claime faire ſiſter
I bare it in the intereſt of my wife,
Tis ſhe is ſubcontraed to this Lord
And I her husband contradi the banes,
If you will mary, make your loue to me,
My Lady is beſpoke,thou art arm’d Gloſter,
If none appeare to proue vpon thy head,
Thy hainous,manifeſt,and many treaſons,
There is my pledge,ile proue it on thy heart
Ere I taſt bread, thou art in nothing leſſe
Then I haue here proclaimd thee.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Sicke, ô ſicke.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: If not, ile ne’re truſt poyſon.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Ther’s my exchange, what in the world he is,
That names me traytor,villain-like he lies,
Call by thy trumpet,he that dares approach,
On him,on you,who not,I will maintaine
My truth and honour ﬁrmely.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: A Herald, ho.

speech.speaker: BaSt.
speech.line: A Herald ho,a Herald.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Truſt to thy ſingle vertue,for thy ſouldiers
All leuied in my name, haue in my name
tooke their diſcharge,

speech.speaker: Regan.
speech.line: This ſicknes growes vpon me.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: She is not well,conuey her to my tent,
Come hether Herald,let the trumpet ſound,
And read out this.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Sound trumpet?

speech.speaker: Her.
speech.line: If any man of qualitie or degree, in the hoaſt of the army,
will maintaine vpon Edmund ſuppoſed Earle of Gloſter,
that he’s a manifold traitour, let him appeare by the third
ſound of the trumpet, he is bold in his defence.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Sound?
Againe?

scene.stagedir: Enter Edgar at the third ſound, a trumpet before him.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Aske him his purpoſes why he appeares
Vpon this call oth’ trumpet.

speech.speaker: Her.
speech.line: What are you?
your name and qualitie? And why you anſwere
this preſent ſummons.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: O know my name is loſt
by treaſons tooth. Bare-gnawne and canker-bitte,
yet are I mou’t
Where is the aduerſarie I come to cope with all.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Which is that aduerſarie?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: What’s he that ſpeakes for Edmund Earle of Gloſter,

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Him ſelfe, what ſaieſt thou to him?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Draw thy ſword.
That if my ſpeech oﬀend a noble hart,
thy arme May do thee Iuſtice, here is mine.
Behold it is my priviledge of my tongue,
My oath and my profeſſion, I proteſt,
Maugure thy ſtrength,youth,place,and eminence,
Deſpight thy vior, ſ;word and ﬁre new fortun’d,
Thy valor and thy heart thou art a traytor.
Falſe to thy Gods thy brother and thy Father,
Conſpicuate gainſt this high illuſtrious prince,
And from the’xtreameſt vpward of thy head,
To the deſcent and duſt beneath thy feet,
A moſt toad-ſpotted traytor ſay thou no
This ſword, this arme,and my beſt ſpirits, As bent
to proue vpon thy heart whereto I ſpeake
thou lieſt,

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: In wiſdome I ſholud aske thy name,
But ſince thy outſide lookes ſo faire and warlike,
And that thy being ſome ſay of breeding breathes,
By right of knighthood, I diſdaine and ſpurne
Heere do I toſſe thoſe treaſons to thy head,
With the hell hatedly, oreturnd thy heart,
Which for they yet glance by and ſcarcely bruſe,
This ſword of mine ſhall giue them inſtant way
Where they ſhall reſt for euer, trumpets ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Saue him, ſaue him.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: This is meere praiſe Gloſter
by the law of armes Thou art not bound to anſwere
an vnknowne oppoſite, Thou art not vanquiſht,
but couſned and beguild.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Stop your mouth dame,
or with this paper ſhall I ſtople it,
thou worſe then any thing, reade thine owne euill,
nay no tearing Lady,I perceiue you know’t.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Say if I do, the lawes are mine not thine, who ſhal arraine for’t.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Moſt monſtrous know’ſt thou this paper?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Aske me not what I know.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Go after her,ſhee’s deſperate, gouerne her.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: What you haue chargd me with,
that haue I don
And more, much more, the time will bring it out.
Tis paſt, and ſo am I, but what art thou
That haſt this fortune on me? if thou bee’ſt noble
I do forgiue thee.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Let’s exchange charity,
I am no leſſe in bloud then thou art Edmond,
If more, the more thou haſt wrongd me.
My name is Edgar, and thy fathers ſonne,
The Gods are ioſt, and of our pleaſant vertues.
Make inſtruments to ſcourge vs
the darke and vitious Place where thee he gotte,
coſt him his cies.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Thou haſt ſpoken truth,
the wheele is come full circled I am heere.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Me thought thy very gate did prophecie,
A royall nobleneſſe I muſt embrace thee.
Let ſorow ſplit my heart if I did euer
hate thee or thy father.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Worthy Prince I know’t.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Where haue you hid your ſelfe?
How haue you knowne the miſeries of your father?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: By nurſing them my Lord, Liſt a briefe tale,
and when tis told O that my heart would burſt
the bloudy proclamation To eſcape
that followed me ſo neere, O our liues ſweetnes,
that with the paine of death, Would hourly die,
rather then die at once. Taught me to ſhift
