into a mad-mans rags To aſſume a ſemblance
that very dogges diſdain’d And in this habit
met I my father with his bleeding rings,
The precious ſtones new loſt became his guide,
Led him, beg’d for him, ſau’d him from diſpaire,
Neuer (O Father) reueald my ſelfe vnto him,
Vntill ſome halfe houre paſt, when I was armed,
Not ſure, though hoping of this good ſucceſſe,
I askt his bleſſing, and from ﬁrſt to laſt,
Told him my pilgrimage, but his ﬂawd heart,
Alacke too weake the conﬂi to ſupport,
Twixt two extreames of paſſion,ioy and griefe,
Burſt ſmillingly.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: This ſpeech of yours hath moued me,
And ſhall perchance do good,but ſpeake you on,
You looke as you had ſomething more to ſay.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: If there be more,more wofull, hold it in,
For I am almoſt ready to diſſolue,
hearing of this.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: This would haue ſeemd a periode to ſuch
As loue not ſorow,but another to amplifie too much,
Would make much more, and top exxtreamitie
Whil’ſ I was big in clamor, came there in a man,
Who hauing ſeene me in my worſt eſtate,
Shund my abhord ſociety, but then ﬁnding
Who twas that ſo indur’d with his ſtrong armes
He faſtened on my necke and bellowed out,
As hee’d burſt heauen,threw me on my father,
Told the moſt pitious tale of Lear and him,
That euer care received, which in recounting
His greifegrew puiſlant and the ſtrings of life,
Began to cracke twice, then the trumpets founded.
And there I left him traunſt.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: But who was this.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Kent ſir, the baniſt Kent,
who in diguiſe, Followed his enemie king and did him ſeruice
Improper for a ſlaue.

scene.stagedir: Enter one with a bloudie knife,

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Helpe, helpe,

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: What kinde of helpe, what meanes that bloudy knife?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Its hot it ſmokes, it came euen from the heart of —

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Who man, ſpeake?

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: Your Lady ſir, your Lady, and her ſiſter
By her is poyſoned, ſhe hath confeſt it.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I was contraed to them both, all three
Now marie in an inſtant.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Produce their bodies, be they aliue or dead,
This Iuſtice of the heauens that makes vs tremble,
Touches vs not with pity.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Here comes Kent ſir.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: O tis he,
The complement that very manners vrges.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I am come
to bid my King and maiſteray good night,
Is he not here?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Great thing of vs forgot,
Speake Edmund, whers the king, and whers Cordelia
Seeſt thou this obie Kent.

scene.stagedir: The bodies of Gonorill and Regan are brought in,

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Alack why thus.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Yet Edmund was beloued,
The one the other poyſoned for my ſake,
And after ſlue her ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Duke
speech.line: Euen ſo, couer their faces.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I pant for life, ſome good I meane to do,
Deſpight of my owne nature, quickly ſend,
Be briefe, inttoth’ caſtle for my writ,
Is on the life of Lear and on Cordelia,
Nay ſend in time.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Runne,runne,O runne.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: To who my Lord, who hath the oﬃce,
ſend Thy token of repreeue.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Well thought on, take my ſword
the Captaine, Give it the Captaine?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Haſt thee for thy life.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: He hath Commiſſion from thy wife and me,
To hang Cordelia in the priſon, and
to lay The blame vpon her owne deſpaire,
That ſhe fordid her ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: The Gods defend her, beare him hence a while.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lear with Cordelia in his armes.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Howle,howle.howle,howle. O you are men of ſtones,
Had I your tongues and eyes, I would vſe them ſo,
That heauens vault ſhould cracke,ſhees gone for euer,
I know when one is dead and when one liues,
Shees dead as earth, lend me a looking glaſſe,
If that her breath will miſt or ſtaine the ſtone,
Why then ſhe liues.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Is this the promist end.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Or image of that horror.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Fall and ceaſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: This feather ſtirs ſhe liues, if it be ſo,
It is a chance which do’s redeeme all ſorowes
That euer I haue felt.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: A my good maiſter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Prethe away?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Tis Noble Kent your friend.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: A plague vpon your murderous traytors all,
I might haue ſaued her, now ſhees gone for euer,
Cordelia, Cordelia, ſtay a little, ha,
What iſt thou ſayeſt, her voyce was euer ſoft,
Gentle and low, an excellent thing in women,
I kild the ſlaue that was a hanging thee.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Tis true my Lords, he did.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Did I not fellow?
I haue ſeene the day, With my good biting Fauchon
I would Haue made him skippe, I am old now,
And theſe ſame croſſes ſpoyle me, who are you?
Mine eyes are not othe beſt, ile tell you ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: If Fortune bragd of two ſhe loued or hated,
One of them we behold.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Are not you Kent?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: The ſame your ſeruant Kent,
where is your ſeruant Caius,

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Hees a good fellow, I can tell that,
Heele ſtrike and quickly too, hees dead and rotten.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: No my good Lord,I am the very man.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ile ſee that ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: That from your life of diﬀerence and decay,
Haue followed your ſad ſteps.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: You’r welcome hither.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Nor no man elſe,
als chearles, darke and deadly,
Your eldeſt daughters haue foredoome themſelues,
And deſperatly are dead

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: So thinke I to.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: He knowes not what he ſees, and vaine it is,
That we preſent vs to him.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Very bootleſſe.

speech.speaker: Capt.
speech.line: Edmund is dead my Lord.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Thats but a triﬂe heere,
you Lords and noble friends, Know our intent,
what comfort to this decay may come,
ſhall be applied: for vs we wil reſigne
during the life of this old maieſty,
to him our abſolute power, you to your rights
with boote, and ſuch addition as your honor
haue more then merited,all friends ſhall
taſt the wages of their vertue,and al foes
the cup of their deſeruings, O ſee, ſee.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: And my poore foole is hangd, no, no life,
why ſhould a dog,a horſe, a rat of life
and thou no breath at all, O thou wilt come no more,
neuer,neuer,neuer,
pray you vndo this button, thanke you ſir,O, o,o,o.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: He faints my Lord,my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Breake hart,I prethe breake.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Looke vp my Lord.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Vex not his ghoſt, O let him paſſe, He hates him
that would vpon the wracke, Of this tough world
ſtretch him out longer.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: O he is gon indeed.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: The wonder is, he hath endured ſo long,
He but vſurpt his life.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Beare them from hence, our preſent buſines
Is to generall woe, friends of my ſoule, you twaine,
Rule in this kingdome,and the goard ſtate ſuſtaine.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I haue a iourney ſir, ſhortly to go,
My maiſter cals, and I muſt not ſay no.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: The waight of this ſad time we muſt obey,
Speake what we feele. not what we ought to ſay,
The oldeſt haue borne moſt, we that are yong,
Shall neuer ſee ſo much, nor liue ſo long.
